revision.text:
{{distinguish|Abhyankar's lemma}}
In [[abstract algebra]], '''Abhyankar's conjecture''' is a 1957 [[conjecture]] of [[Shreeram Abhyankar]], on the [[Galois group]]s of [[algebraic function field]]s of [[Characteristic (algebra)|characteristic]] ''p''.<ref>{{Citation |last=Abhyankar |first=Shreeram |year=1957 |title=Coverings of Algebraic Curves |journal=[[American Journal of Mathematics]] |volume=79 |issue=4 |pages=825–856 |doi=10.2307/2372438 }}.</ref> The soluble case was solved by Serre in 1990<ref>{{citation | last=Serre | first=Jean-Pierre | authorlink=Jean-Pierre Serre | title=Construction de revêtements étales de la droite affine en caractéristique p | language=French | zbl=0726.14021 | journal=Comptes Rendus de l'Académie des Sciences, Série I | volume=311 | number=6 | pages=341–346 | year=1990 }}</ref> and the full conjecture was proved in 1994 by work of [[Michel Raynaud]] and [[David Harbater]].<ref>{{Citation |first=Michel |last=Raynaud |title=Revêtements de la droite affine en caractéristique p > 0 |journal=Inventiones Mathematicae |volume=116 |issue=1 |year=1994 |pages=425–462 | doi=10.1007/BF01231568 | zbl=0798.14013 |bibcode=1994InMat.116..425R }}.</ref><ref>{{Citation |first=David |last=Harbater |year=1994 |title=Abhyankar's conjecture on Galois groups over curves |journal=Inventiones Mathematicae |volume=117 |issue=1 |pages=1–25 | doi=10.1007/BF01232232 | zbl=0805.14014 |bibcode=1994InMat.117....1H }}.</ref><ref name=FJ70>{{citation | last1=Fried | first1=Michael D. | last2=Jarden | first2=Moshe | title=Field arithmetic | edition=3rd | series=Ergebnisse der Mathematik und ihrer Grenzgebiete. 3. Folge | volume=11 | publisher=[[Springer-Verlag]] | year=2008 | isbn=978-3-540-77269-9 | zbl=1145.12001 | page=70 }}</ref>
The problem involves a [[finite group]] ''G'', a [[prime number]] ''p'', and the [[function field of an algebraic variety|function field]] of nonsingular integral [[algebraic curve]] ''C'' defined over an [[algebraically closed]] [[Field (mathematics)|field]] ''K'' of characteristic ''p''.
The question addresses the existence of [[Galois extension]]s ''L'' of ''K''(''C''), with ''G'' as Galois group, and with restricted [[Ramification (mathematics)|ramification]]. From a geometric point of view ''L'' corresponds to another curve ''C''′, and a [[morphism]]
:π : ''C''′ → ''C''.
Ramification geometrically, and by analogy with the case of [[Riemann surface]]s, consists of a finite set ''S'' of points ''x'' on ''C'', such that π restricted to the complement of ''S'' in ''C'' is an [[étale morphism]]. In Abhyankar's conjecture, ''S'' is fixed, and the question is what ''G'' can be. This is therefore a special type of [[inverse Galois problem]].
The subgroup ''p''(''G'') is defined to be the subgroup generated by all the [[Sylow subgroup]]s of ''G'' for the prime number ''p''. This is a [[normal subgroup]], and the parameter ''n'' is defined as the minimum number of generators of
:''G''/''p''(''G'').
Then for the case of ''C'' the [[projective line]] over ''K'', the conjecture states that ''G'' can be realised as a Galois group of ''L'', unramified outside ''S'' containing ''s'' + 1 points, if and only if
:''n'' ≤ ''s''.
This was proved by Raynaud.
For the general case, proved by Harbater, let ''g'' be the [[Genus (mathematics)|genus]] of ''C''. Then ''G'' can be realised if and only if
:''n'' ≤ ''s'' + 2 ''g''.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{MathWorld|urlname=AbhyankarsConjecture|title=Abhyankar's conjecture}} * [http://www.math.purdue.edu/about/purview/spring95/conjecture.html A layman's perspective of Abhyankar's conjecture] from [[Purdue University]]
[[Category:Algebraic curves]] [[Category:Conjectures]] [[Category:Galois theory]] [[Category:Theorems in abstract algebra]] [[Category:Conjectures that have been proved]]

{{Religious text primary|date=May 2016}}
{{Other uses|Abomination (disambiguation){{!}}Abomination}} '''Abomination''' (from [[Latin]] ''[[Glossary of ancient Roman religion#abdominare|abominare]]'', "to deprecate as an ill omen") is an [[English language|English]] term used to translate the [[Hebrew Bible|Biblical Hebrew]] terms '''shiqquts''' שיקוץ and '''sheqets''' שקץ,<ref>Stone Edition Chumash {{ISBN|1-57819-107-6}}</ref> which are derived from '''shâqats''', or the terms תֹּועֵבָה, '''tōʻēḇā''' or '''to'e'va''' (noun) or '''ta'ev''' (verb). An abomination in English is that which is exceptionally loathsome, [[hate]]ful, [[sin]]ful, [[evil|wicked]], or vile.
The Biblical words usually translated as "abomination" do not always convey the same sense of moral exceptionalism as the English term does today, as it often may signify that which is forbidden or unclean according to the religion (especially ''sheqets''). Linguistically in this case, it may be closer in meaning to the Polynesian term [[taboo]] or ''tapu'', signifying that which is forbidden, and should not be eaten, and or not touched, and which sometimes was a capital crime. The word most often translated "abomination" to denote grave moral offenses is ''Tōʻēḇā.'' This article examines the term as it is used in English translations of the [[Bible]], and also the actual senses of the words which are being translated into this term in English.<ref>Hebrew/English dictionaries. Strong's Concordance of the Bible.</ref>
The term ''shiqquts'' is translated ''abomination'' by almost all translations of the Bible. The similar words, ''sheqets'', and ''shâqats'', are almost exclusively used for dietary violations.
The common but slighty different Hebrew term, ''tōʻēḇā'', is also translated as ''abomination'' in the [[Authorized King James Version]], and sometimes in the [[New American Standard Bible|NASB]]. Many modern versions of the Bible (including the [[New International Version|NIV]] and [[New English Translation|NET]]) translate it ''detestable''; the [[New American Bible|NAB]] translates it ''loathsome''. It is mainly used to denote idolatry; and in many other cases it refers to inherently [[evil]]<ref>"inherently evil": things, words, deeds which ''of their very nature'' ["[[intrinsic and extrinsic properties (philosophy)|intrinsic property]]"] are always harmful, degrading, debasing, dehumanizing or lethal to the human person (but frequently deemed by some opportunists to be most useful and convenient, thinking "the end always justifies the means") and which,by extension, are always harmful and eventually lethal to the nature and stability of human culture and society--"evil". Biblical references: Leviticus 18:6-30; Leviticus 20. Deuteronomy 12:29-31; 23:17-19; 25:13-16; 27:16-25. Compare Romans 1:23; 3:8; 13:9-10; Galatians 5:19-21.</ref> things such as illicit sex, lying, murder, deceit, etc.; and for unclean foods.
Another word which can signify that which is abhorred is '''zâ‛am'''. There are less used Hebrew words with a similar conveyance, as well as Greek terms for such.
__TOC__
==Analysis of the term==
===Shiqquts=== ''Shiqquts'' is used in the following ways:
# In Daniel's prophecies in {{bibleverse||Daniel|11:31|NIV}} (cf. 12:11), it is generally interpreted as referring to the fearful calamities that were to fall on the [[Jew]]s in the time of [[Antiochus IV Epiphanes]], saying "And they shall place the abomination that maketh desolate." Jerome, and most of the Christian fathers, suppose that the reference is to Antiochus as the type of Antichrist, and that the description passes from the type to the antitype.<ref>Albert Barnes commentary</ref> Idolatry is presented as the chief [[sin]] in the Bible, and shiqquts is often used to describe such. # In his campaign of [[Hellenistic|Hellenization]], [[Antiochus IV Epiphanes|Antiochus]] caused an altar to be erected on the altar for burnt-offerings of the [[Second Temple]], on which pig sacrifices were offered to [[Zeus]] [[Mount Olympus|Olympios]]. (Comp. [[wikisource:Bible (King James)/1 Maccabees#Chapter 1|1 Maccabees 1:54]]). Following the wording of {{bibleverse||Daniel|9:27|NIV}}, this may have been the [[abomination of desolation]] of [[Jerusalem]]. <!-- UNSOURCED STATEMENT FROM August 2008 *** # In {{bibleverse||Matthew|24:15|NIV}}, the reference is probably to the image-crowned standards which the Romans set up at the east gate of the Temple (70 AD), and to which they paid homage. "Almost the entire religion of the Roman camp consisted in worshipping the ensign, swearing by the ensign, and in preferring the ensign before all other gods."{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} These ensigns were an "abomination" to the Jews, the "abomination of desolation." *** --> #sinful sacrifices ({{bibleverse||Isaiah|66:3|NIV}}) #idolatry ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|29:17|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Ezekiel|20:7,8|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||1Kings|11:5-7|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|13:27|KJV}}) #witchcraft ({{bibleverse|2|Kings|23:24|KJV}})
The word ''sheqets'' is used with eating: #seafood that lacks fins and scales ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:10-12|NASB}}) #all insects except for locust, crickets and grasshoppers ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:20-23|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:41|NASB}}) #eagles, [[ossifrage]], and the osprey ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:13|KJV}}) other biblically [[unclean animals]] or touching certain things,({{bibleverse||Leviticus|7:21|NASB}})
''Shâqats'' is rendered in the KJV as follows:
#abominable ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:43|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Leviticus|20:25|KJV}}) #abomination ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:11|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Leviticus|11:13|KJV}}) #abhorred ({{bibleverse||Psalms|22:24|KJV}}) #detest ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|7:26|KJV}})
===Tōʻēḇā=== ''Tōʻēḇā'' is used in the following ways:
#Every [[shepherd]] was "an abomination" unto the [[Egyptians]] ({{bibleverse||Genesis|46:34|NASB}}). # [[Pharaoh]] was so moved by the [[Plagues of Egypt|fourth plague]], that while he refused the demand of [[Moses]], he offered a compromise, granting to the [[Israelites]] permission to hold their festival and offer their sacrifices in Egypt. This permission could not be accepted, because [[Moses]] said they would have to sacrifice "the abomination of the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]]" ({{bibleverse||Exodus|8:26|NASB}}); i.e., the cow or ox, which all the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]] held as sacred and so regarded as [[sacrilegious]] to kill. #{{bibleverse||Proverbs|6:16-19|NASB}} lists seven things which are also abominations: "haughty eyes, a lying tongue, hands that shed innocent blood, a heart that devises wicked schemes, feet that are swift in running to mischief, a false witness who utters lies, and one who spreads strife among brothers."
''Tōʻēḇā'' is also used in Jewish (and Christian Old Testament) scriptures to refer to:
#[[idolatry]] or idols ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|7:25|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|13:14|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Isaiah|44:19|NASB}}) #illicit sex (e.g prostitution, adultery, incest) ({{bibleverse||Ezekiel|16:22,58|KJV}}, {{bibleverse||Ezekiel|22:11|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Ezekiel|33:26|NASB}}) #illicit marriage ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|24:2-4|NASB}}) #male [[prostitution]] and/or other [[Gay|male homosexual acts]] (see [[Homosexuality in the Hebrew Bible]]) ({{bibleverse||Leviticus|18:22|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Leviticus|18:27-30|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Leviticus|20:13|NASB}}) #[[temple prostitution]] ({{bibleverse||1Kings|14:24|KJV}}) #offerings from the above ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|23:18|NASB}}) #[[child sacrifice]] to Molech ({{bibleverse||Jeremiah|32:35|KJV}}) #[[cross-dressing]] ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|22:5|NASB}}) #cheating in the market by using rigged weights ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|25:13-19|NASB}}, {{bibleverse||Proverbs|11:1|NAS}}) #dishonesty ({{bibleverse||Proverbs|12:22|NASB}}) #dietary violations ({{bibleverse||Deuteronomy|14:3|KJV}}) #stealing, murder, and adultery, breaking covenants ({{bibleverse||Jeremiah|7:9,10|KJV}}) # [[usury]], violent robbery, murder, oppressing the poor and needy, etc. ({{bibleverse||Ezekiel|18:10-13|KJV}})
''Tâ‛ab'' is rendered the following ways in the KJV
#abhor, 9 Deu_7:26, Deu_23:7 (2), Job_9:31, Job_30:10, Psa_5:6, Psa_119:163, Amo_5:10, Mic_3:9; #abominable, 6 1Ch_21:6, Job_15:16, Psa_53:1 (2), Isa_14:19, Eze_16:52; #abhorred, 3 Job_19:19, Psa_106:40, Eze_16:25; #abhorreth, 2 Psa_107:18, Isa_49:7; #abominably, 1 1Ki_21:26; #committed, 1 Eze_16:52.
==See also== * [[The Bible and homosexuality]] * [[Damnation]] * [[Fire and brimstone]] * [[Gehinnom]] * [[Hell]] * [[Leviticus 18]] * [[Religion and homosexuality]] * [[Shiksa]] and [[shegetz]], [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] slang words deriving from ''sheqets'' * [[Tophet]] * [[Total depravity]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2012}}
'''Armenian PowerSpell''' — the electronic corrector for texts in the [https://web.archive.org/web/20101127023113/http://www.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=hye modern] [[Armenian language]] used in [[Armenia]]. Checks spelling,<ref name="langwiki">[http://www.iranianlinguistics.org/wiki/index.php?title=Armenian iranianlinguistics.org Armenian] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726190143/http://www.iranianlinguistics.org/wiki/index.php?title=Armenian |date=2011-07-26 }}</ref> grammar, punctuation,<ref name="edu">[http://www.armedu.am/arm/official.php?sec=news&id=3962 Armenian Educational Portal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706072337/http://www.armedu.am/arm/official.php?sec=news&id=3962 |date=2011-07-06 }}</ref> slang and some semantic errors specific to texts in the [[Armenian language]]. Program was widely adopted in Armenia,<ref name="german">[http://haymat.de/?p=13 Haymat.De - About PowerSpell 2009: Rechtschreib-und Grammatikprüfung für die armenische Sprache (Press Release)]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="pcnews" /> and among the [[Armenian diaspora]]<ref name="inter">[http://interactive.banadzev.com/?p=1546 Interactive Banadzev] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707210204/http://interactive.banadzev.com/?p=1546 |date=July 7, 2011 }}</ref> which uses the modern [[Armenian language]]. Today the product is used by almost all state and many educational institutions<ref name="pcnews">[http://www.pcnews.am/it-armenia/it-zargacum/1429--powerspell.html PC News Armenia (Press Release) ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120422213557/http://www.pcnews.am/it-armenia/it-zargacum/1429--powerspell.html |date=April 22, 2012 }}</ref><ref name="court">[http://soft.areg.biz/downloads/poweroffice/2010/eng/clients.htm List of organizations using Armenian PowerSpell]</ref> of [[Armenia]].
== Singularities == As it is described in the overview article on a product site,<ref name="article">[http://soft.areg.biz/downloads/poweroffice/2010/statia.htm Review Article in Russian]</ref> it is developed specially for realities of the modern Armenia taking into account many foreign words which were extended in the Armenian language during the Soviet and Post-Soviet periods.<ref name="arka1">[http://telecom.arka.am/rus/it/2009/07/21/2034.html ARKA IT News - About PowerSpell 2010 (Press Release)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706072334/http://telecom.arka.am/rus/it/2009/07/21/2034.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> A singularity of a product that it checks errors specific to people with Russian education, and it is adapted on parallel training of the user to the Armenian language. In particular the product is capable to translate the text with usage of the Armenian slang in its literary format, and also to display learning hints. Many words speaking another language used in the Armenian texts, formally don't exist in the Armenian language because of what have no strict rules of a spelling, however the product wide circulation has allowed to standardize writing of many terms and words speaking another language.
== Possibilities<ref name="compare">[http://soft.areg.biz/downloads/poweroffice/2010/eng/compare.htm PowerSpell functions list]</ref> == The following information related to Armenian PowerSpell 2011 * Spelling, on the basis of the basic dictionary in 850,000 words * Check about 7 million word forms and sheaves of words. * Check of grammar and a punctuation with an output of learning helps * Check of a slang with transfer possibility in a literary format * Check of words speaking another language and terms * Check of wrong declinations of correctly made words (specific to the Armenian language) * Check of words with double sense on the correct use * the Restricted analysis of sentences on possibility of the passed word.
== Platforms == The product is supported for a platform of [[Microsoft Windows]] and integrated into all versions of [[Microsoft Office]] 2000—2010, old versions worked only in Microsoft Word
== History<ref name="huys">[http://www.hooys.com/PDFs/PDF_53(low).pdf Newspaper "Hooys" No. 53 ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712215806/http://www.hooys.com/PDFs/PDF_53%28low%29.pdf |date=July 12, 2011 }}</ref> == Older versions of a product were called Armenian Orfo (ArmOrfo) * 2000 — Armenian Orfo (ArmOrfo) 2000 (only spelling, based on dictionary with 130,000 words)<ref name="hayjam"> [http://hzh.am/Arkhiv/2005/December/24.12/24.12.05.html Newspaper "Haykakan Jamanak", from Dec. 2005] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706072618/http://hzh.am/Arkhiv/2005/December/24.12/24.12.05.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> * 2005 — Armenian PowerSpell 2005 (only spelling, based on dictionary with 200,000 words)<ref name="hayjam" /> * 2009 — Armenian PowerSpell 2009 (spelling, grammar and non-Armenian words checker, based on dictionary with 570,000 words) * 2010 — Armenian PowerSpell 2011 <ref name="newsam">[http://news.am/arm/news/37172.html Armenia News - Armenian PowerSpell 2011 is more competent than the predecessor (Press Release)]</ref>
== Criticism == The first release of the program PowerSpell 2009 from March, 1st 2009, was exposed to the rigid criticism for the high price policy, critics however recognized that program was most complete solution for spelling of the Armenian language.<ref name="pa">[http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/world/detail/44733 PanArmenian.Net - Spelling in Armenian no longer a problem (Press Release)]</ref> Meanwhile distributors don't agree with this judgement stating that the price policy ($24 per year, including annual new versions) programs is accessible to the country population, as has served its propagation.<ref name="itel" />
== Known Problems == According to information present on product website,<ref name="site">[http://soft.areg.biz/downloads/poweroffice/2010/problem/problem.htm Installation Problems]</ref> the program uses macro program to integrate itself into Microsoft Office. In case if macro security level is high, then program will not be installed correctly.
== Distribution == Program is distributed by the company "Sahak Partev Papian" registered in Armenia.
== Struggle against a piracy == Piracy propagation of a product, has led to the full paralysis of its development<ref name="itel">[http://www.itel.am/en-news-2-2729.html Mediamax Agency - Interview with the author and distributor of PowerSpell 2009 (Press Release)]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> in 2002, activity on product development has been stopped up to 2005. New realities of Armenia allow to struggle with a piracy through judicial instances, the law on the copyright became better to be observed,<ref name="ms">[http://www.telecom.arka.am/rus/it/2010/11/17/5577.html ARKA IT News (Press Release)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706072320/http://www.telecom.arka.am/rus/it/2010/11/17/5577.html |date=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> in particular, after discovery of [http://www.micarmenia.am/ representation Microsoft in Armenia].
== See also== Modern Armenian language [[spell checker]] programs * [http://sourceforge.net/projects/armspell/ Armspell Project] * [http://office.microsoft.com/en-in/downloads/office-language-interface-pack-lip-downloads-HA001113350.aspx Microsoft Armenian Language Pack]
== Related External Links == * [http://www.powerspell.am Official page of Armenian PowerSpell] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110706072902/http://www.norq.am/home/lng/1/id/164/tt_newsMore.html Norq.Am - Armenian PowerSpell recognizes 97% of Armenian words and correct mistakes] * [http://www.lezu.am/?p=418 Armenian Language National Inspectorate - Armenian PowerSpell 2011 provides 99% of language coverage (Press Release)] * [http://itel.am/en-news-2-3480.html Mediamax Agency - New version of Armenian PowerSpell available (Press Release)]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/it_telecom/news/49807/ PanArmenian.Net - Armenian PowerSpell 2010 program version to be released] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100520092914/http://hetq.am/en/technologies/hayots-lezu/ Hetq (Newspaper)- New Armenian Spell Check Program 97% Accurate] * [http://www.itel.am/ru-news-2-3519.html Interview to agency Mediamax and portal Itel.am - Armenian PowerSpell 2011 has solved a new complex of tasks (Russian)]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
== References == <References/>

{{one source|date=May 2014}} [[Image:Misionáři obracejí na katolickou víru.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Bridel [[Counter-Reformation|re-catholicizing]] the Czech people]] '''Bedřich Bridel''', or '''Fridrich Bridelius''' ({{lang-de|'''Friedrich Briedel, Bridelius'''}}; 1619, [[Vysoké Mýto]] – October 15, 1680, [[Kutná Hora]]) was a [[Czech people|Czech]] [[baroque]] writer, poet, and missionary.
== Biography == He studied at the [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] [[gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] in [[Prague]]. In 1637 he entered the Jesuit order, he was ordained as a priest around 1650.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite book|title=Slovník českých spisovatelů|last=|first=|authorlink=|editor1=Věra Menclová |editor2=Václav Vaněk|year=2005|publisher=Libri|location=[[Prague]]|isbn=80-7277-179-5|pages=96–97|url= |language=cs}}</ref> From 1656 to 1660 he led the printing office of the Jesuits in the Prague [[Clementinum]]. Following the 1660 he devoted himself exclusively to the missionary and predicatory activities in Bohemia.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> He died of [[Bubonic plague|plague]].
== Work == Bridel's literary output is varied, he used more forms and genres. The majority of his works are catechetic books. He also translated the German and Latin texts into Czech.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
=== List of selected works === * ''Co Bůh? Člověk?'' (''What God? Man?'') – a long meditative poem that is regarded today as one of the most important works of the Bohemian baroque poetry * ''Život svatého Ivana'', 1656 (''The life of the saint Ivan'') * ''Stůl Páně'' (''The table of the Lord'') * ''František svatý Xaver'' (''Saint Francis of Xavier'') * ''Sláva Svatoprokopská'', 1662 (''The glory of the saint Prokop'') * ''Katechismus katolický'' (''Catholic catechism'')
==See also== {{portal|Poetry}} * [[List of Czech writers]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = C. R. Simha | image = C.R.Simha-pic.jpg | image_size = 225px | caption = | birth_name = Channapatna Ramaswamy Simha | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1942|06|16}} | birth_place = [[Channapatna]], [[Kingdom of Mysore]], British India | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2014|02|28|1942|06|16}} | death_place = [[Bangalore]], Karnataka, India | nationality = Indian | occupation = Actor, director | spouse = Sharada Simha | relatives = [[Srinath]] (brother) }} [[File:A portrait of Shri C.R.Simha who will be presented with the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for Theatre - Acting (Kannada)by the President Dr. A.P.J Abdul Kalam in New Delhi on October 26, 2004.jpg|thumb|A portrait of Shri C.R.Simha who will be presented with the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award for Theatre - Acting (Kannada)by the President Dr. A.P.J Abdul Kalam in New Delhi on October 26, 2004]] '''Channapatna Ramaswami Simha''' (16 June 1942 – 28 February 2014), better known as '''C. R. Simha''', was an Indian actor, director, dramatist and playwright. He was best known for his work in [[Kannada language|Kannada]] films and for his work in stage shows. Starting his career in [[Prabhat Kalavidaru]], a famous theatre group based in Bangalore, he acted in numerous Kannada plays which reached the [[cult]] status. He started his own theatre group called "Nataranga" in 1972 and directed many successful plays such as ''[[Kakana Kote]]'', ''Thughlaq'' and ''Sankranthi''.
Simha also directed and acted in the Kannada adaptation of [[Shakespeare]]'s ''[[Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' and ''[[Othello]]''. These plays found a widespread presentation across many states in India. Following this, he directed and acted in many English plays written by eminent personalities such as [[Moliere]], [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]], [[Edward Albee]] and [[Neil Simon]] among others. Apart from theatre, Simha acted in more than 150 feature films in Kannada which include both artistic and commercially viable projects. He also directed about five feature films with the most prominent being his own film adaptation of ''Kakana Kote''.
Simha received many awards in both the cinema and theatre fields. In 2003, he was awarded with the prestigious [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]] by the [[Government of India]] recognising his contribution to theatre acting and direction.<ref>{{cite news |title= Sangeet Natak Akademi awards for 33 |url= http://www.hindu.com/2003/12/02/stories/2003120203871300.htm |newspaper=Deccan Herald |date= 2 December 2003}}</ref>
==Early life== Simha was born in [[Karnataka]] on 16 June 1942 into a Hoysala Karnataka Brahmin family. His younger brother [[Srinath]] is a famous film actor who acted in several mainstream Kannada cinema as both the leading actor and supporting actor.
Simha appeared on stage at the age of twelve. He wrote a book at the age of thirteen titled "Family Doctor" and got a publisher for a remuneration of {{INR}}15. He was a student of National College at Basavanagudi, Bangalore. In 1959, he joined the National College Histronics Club, an institution nurtured by [[Hosur Narasimhaiah|Dr. H. Narasimhaiah]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Farewell, thespian CR Simha |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/theatre/Farewell-thespian-CR-Simha/articleshow/31199429.cms |newspaper=The Times of India |date= 1 March 2014 |accessdate= 2 March 2014}}</ref> Simha then acted in many Kannada plays like "Bahaddur Ganda" and "Manavemba Markata".
==Career==
===Theatre=== Simha, along with his friends, started a theatre group called "Nataranga" in 1972. He acted in and directed many successful plays like ''Kakana Kote'' and ''Tughlaq''.
Simha also acted in and directed straight translations of [[Shakespeare]]'s plays such as ''[[Midsummer Night's Dream]]'' and ''[[Othello]]'', which besides Karnataka, were also performed in Delhi, Bombay (Mumbai), Madras (Chennai) & Calcutta (Kolkata). In 1960, Simha became a member of "Bangalore Little Theatre" (BLT) and since then directed some of the reputed English plays which included his portrayal of Cyrano de Bergerac which was hailed as a memorable performance. His other notable works for BLT were [[Utpal Dutt]]'s ''Suryashikar'' and [[Girish Karnad]]'s ''Thuglaq''.
In 1983, Simha started another theatre group called "Vedhike" in which his one-man show ''Typical Kailasam'' became a success. It was the first amateur Kannada play to be performed abroad (in the United States of America, Canada and England). Some of the other notable plays which made news through "Vedhike" are ''Meese Bandoru'', ''Bhairavi'', ''Karna'', ''Rasa Rishi Kuvempu'', ''Macbeth'', ''Maduve Maduve'', ''Haavu Yeni'' and ''8/15''. Among these, ''Rasa Rishi Kuvempu'', based on the life and literature of [[Kuvempu]], was made into a film, directed by Simha's son Rithwik Simha, in which Simha plays the role of Kuvempu.
===Films=== Besides making his strong presence in theatre, Simha was also a popular mainstream character actor in numerous Kannada films. He acted in close to 150 feature films. His portrayal of roles varied from critically acclaimed award-winning films like ''[[Samskara (film)|Samskara]]'', ''[[Bara (film)|Bara]]'', ''Chithegoo Chinte'' and ''Anuroopa'' and also in commercially acclaimed films such as ''Indina Ramayana'', ''[[Nee Bareda Kadambari]]'', ''[[Parameshi Prema Prasanga]]'', ''[[Rayaru Bandaru Mavana Manege]]'' and ''Nee Thanda Kanike''. Simha played negative roles, against [[Anant Nag]] in [[Ramapurada Ravana]] (1984) and with [[Dr. Rajkumar]] in [[Parashuram (film)|Parashuram]] (1990). Simha's villainous role in [[Parashuram (film)|Parashuram]] was said to be very menacing.
Besides acting, Simha has directed five films including ''[[Kakana Kote]]'' (1977), ''Shikaari'', ''Simhasana'', ''[[Ashwamedha (film)|Ashwamedha]]'' (1990) and ''Angayalli Apsare'' (1993).
===Television=== Simha made his strong presence in television too and acted in several tele-serials in Kannada, Hindi and English languages. This includes the most famous worldwide serial ''[[Malgudi Days (TV series)|Malgudi Days]]''. Another noteworthy serial was ''Goruru in America'' based on the travelogue written by the humorist [[Gorur Ramaswamy Iyengar]]. Simha played the part of Gorur and the serial was shot extensively in America including Newyork, Washington D.C., Niagara Falls, Disneyland and Universal Studios – Hollywood.
===Publications=== Simha wrote and published five plays in Kannada. He was a popular columnist, he wrote a column called "Nimma Simha" every Friday for six years in the popular daily newspaper [[Vijaya Karnataka]] and three volumes of this are published in the Book forum.
==Filmography== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * ''[[Samskara (film)|Samskara]]'' (1970) * ''[[Sankalpa]]'' (1973) * ''[[Kanneshwara Rama]]'' (1977) * ''[[m:kn:ಅನುರೂಪ (ಚಲನಚಿತ್ರ)|Anuroopa]]'' (1977) * ''[[m:kn:ಚಿತೆಗೂ ಚಿಂತೆ|Chitegu Chinte]]'' (1978) * ''[[m:kn:ಭೂಮಿಗೆ ಬಂದ ಭಗವಂತ|Bhoomige Banda Bhagavanta]]'' (1981) * ''[[m:kn:ಪ್ರಾಯ ಪ್ರಾಯ ಪ್ರಾಯ|Praya Praya Praya]]'' (1982) * ''[[m:kn:ಅಜಿತ್ (ಚಲನಚಿತ್ರ)|Ajith]]'' (1982) * ''[[Bara (film)|Bara]]'' (1983) * ''[[Simhasana]]'' (1983) * ''[[m:kn:ಸುಖ ಸಂಸಾರಕ್ಕೆ ೧೨ ಸೂತ್ರಗಳು|Sukha Samsarakke 12 Suthragalu]]'' (1984) * ''[[Indina Ramayana]]'' (1984) * ''[[Ramapurada Ravana]]'' (1984) * ''[[m:kn:ತಾಯಿ ಕನಸು|Thayi Kanasu]]'' (1985) * ''[[Parameshi Prema Prasanga]]'' (1985) * ''[[m:kn:ಬ್ರಹ್ಮಗಂಟು|Brahma Gantu]]'' (1985) * ''[[Savira Sullu]]'' (1985) * ''[[Nee Bareda Kadambari]]'' (1985) * ''[[m:kn:ಬೀಗದ ಪಂದ್ಯ|Beegara Pandya]]'' (1986) * ''[[m:kn:ಮದುವೆ ಮಾಡು ತಮಾಷೆ ನೋಡು|Maduve Madu Tamashe Nodu]]'' (1986) * ''[[Nenapina Doni]]'' (1986) * ''[[m:kn:ಬೇಟೆ|Bete]]'' (1986) * ''[[Digvijaya]]'' (1987) * ''[[m:kn:ಬೇಡಿ (ಚಲನಚಿತ್ರ)|Bedi]]'' (1987) * ''[[Shiva Mecchida Kannappa]]'' (1988) * ''[[New Delhi]]'' (1988) * ''[[Balondu Bhavageethe]]'' (1988) * ''[[m:kn:ಕಾಡಿನ ಬೆಂಕಿ|Kadina Benki]]'' (1988) * ''[[Ranaranga]]'' (1988) * ''[[Avane Nanna Ganda]]'' (1989) * ''[[Amanusha]]'' (1989) * ''[[m:kn:ಅವತಾರ ಪುರುಷ|Avathara Purusha]]'' (1989) * ''[[m:kn:ಶರವೇಗದ ಸರದಾರ|Sharavegada Saradara]]'' (1989) * ''[[Sankranthi]]'' (1989) * ''[[Parashuram (film)|Parashuram]]'' (1989) * ''[[m:kn:ಹೊಸ ಕಾವ್ಯ|Hosa Kavya]]'' (1989) * ''[[Krishna Nee Kunidaga]]'' (1989) * ''[[Nammoora Hammera]]'' (1990) * ''[[m:kn:ಕಿಲಾಡಿ ತಾತ|Khiladi Thata]]'' (1990) * ''[[m:kn:ಪೋಲಿ ಕಿಟ್ಟಿ|Poli Kitty]]'' (1990) * ''[[m:kn:ನಕ್ಕಳಾ ರಾಜಕುಮಾರಿ|Nakkala Rajakumari]]'' (1991) * ''[[m:kn:ನವತಾರೆ|Navathare]]'' (1991) * ''[[m:kn:ಎಸ್.ಪಿ.ಭಾರ್ಗವಿ|S. P. Bhargavi]]'' (1991) * ''[[Ksheera Sagara (film)|Ksheera Sagara]]'' (1992) * ''[[m:kn:ಬೆಳ್ಳಿಯಪ್ಪ ಬಂಗಾರಪ್ಪ|Belliyapppa Bangarappa]]'' (1992) * ''[[m:kn:ಝೇಂಕಾರ|Jhenkara]]'' (1992) * ''[[m:kn:ಬಹದ್ದೂರ್ ಹೆಣ್ಣು|Bahaddur Hennu]]'' (1993) * ''[[Rayaru Bandaru Mavana Manege]]'' (1993) * ''[[m:kn:ಅಪೂರ್ವ ಜೋಡಿ|Apoorva Jodi]]'' (1993) * ''[[Chamatkara]]'' (1994) * ''[[Keralida Sarpa]]'' (1994) * ''[[Kona Eedaithe]]'' (1995) * ''[[Thumbida Mane]]'' (1995) * ''[[Himapatha]]'' (1995) * ''Emergency'' (1995) * ''[[Shiva Sainya]]'' (1996) * ''Choo Baana'' (1997) * ''[[Jenina Hole]]'' (1997) * ''[[America America (1997 film)|America America]]'' (1997) * ''Jackie Chan'' (1997) * ''[[Muddina Kanmani]]'' (1997) * ''Kandalli Gundu'' (1997) * ''[[Laali]]'' (1997) * ''[[Mommaga]]'' (1997) * ''[[:m:kn:ಜಗದೀಶ್ವರಿ|Jagadeeshwari]]'' (1998) * ''[[Kurubana Rani]]'' (1998) * ''[[Suvvi Suvvalali]]'' (1998) * ''[[Gadibidi Krishna]]'' (1998) * ''[[Kubera]]'' (1999) * ''Rambhe Nee Vayyarada Gombe'' (1999) * ''Tuvvi Tuvvi Tuvvi'' (1999) * ''Aaha'' (1999) * ''Nannaseya Hoove'' (1999) * ''Balarama'' (2002) * ''Devara Makkalu'' (2003) * ''Om Ganesh'' (2004) * ''Pathi Pathni Avalu'' (2004) * ''[[Gandugali Kumara Rama]]'' (2005) * ''Lancha Samrajya'' (2007) * ''[[Maathaad Maathaadu Mallige]]'' (2007) * ''[[Hani Hani]]'' (2008) * ''Aathmeeya'' (2008) * ''Chikkamagaloora Chikkamallige'' (2009) * ''Swatantra Palya'' (2009) * ''[[Savaari]]'' (2009) * ''Rasarushi Kuvempu'' (2010) * ''[[Prithvi (2010 film)|Prithvi]]'' (2010) ... Home Minister of Karnataka * ''[[Gaana Bajaana]]'' (2010) * ''[[Aidondla Aidu]]'' (2011) * ''[[Gandhi Smiles]]'' (2012) * ''[[Krantiveera Sangolli Rayanna]]'' (2012) * ''[[Veera (2013 film)|Veera]]'' (2013) {{div col end|2}}
==Death== In February 2014, Simha was admitted to Sevakshetra Hospital, [[Bangalore]] having been suffering from [[prostate cancer]] from over a year. He died on 28 February 2014.<ref>{{cite news |title= Veteran actor CR Simha no more | url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news-interviews/Veteran-actor-CR-Simha-no-more/articleshow/31168372.cms? |newspaper=The Times of India |date= 28 February 2014 |accessdate= 2 March 2014}}</ref> On 1 March, his body was kept at the Samsa Bayalu Rangamandira for people to pay homage and his favourite songs were sung by theatre artists. He was cremated at the Banashankari crematorium in Bangalore the same day.<ref>{{cite news |title= C.R. Simha cremated |url= http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/cr-simha-cremated/article5740791.ece |newspaper=The Hindu |date= 2 March 2014 |accessdate= 2 March 2014}}</ref> Simha's last public appearance was at the press meet of the film ''Rasarishi Kuvempu'' in which he played the lead role.<ref>{{cite news |title= CR Simha hospitalized |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/tv/CR-Simha-hospitalized/articleshow/31110599.cms |newspaper=The Times of India |date= 27 February 2014 |accessdate= 2 March 2014}}</ref>

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Capitalization of ''Internet''}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{primary|date=February 2018}} Publishers have different conventions regarding the '''capitalization of ''Internet''''' versus '''''internet''''', when referring to ''the'' [[Internet]], as distinct from generic [[internetworking|internet]]s, or internetworks. Since the widespread deployment of the [[Internet protocol suite]] in the 1980s, the [[Internet Engineering Task Force]] (IETF), the [[Internet Society]], the [[Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN), the [[W3C]], and others have consistently spelled the name of the worldwide network, the Internet, with an initial [[capital letter]] and treated it as a [[proper noun]] in the English language; the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' notes that the global network is usually "the Internet", and most of the historical sources it cites use the capitalized form (in one case "the DARPA internet").{{OED|Internet}} Before the transformation of the [[ARPANET]] into the modern Internet, the term ''internet'' in its lower case spelling was a common short form of the term [[internetwork]], and this spelling and use may still be found in discussions of networking. The spelling "internet" has become commonly used, as the word virtually always refers to the global network; the generic sense of the word has become rare. In some of the first printed mentions of the Internet, like many other US government projects of the period, it was referred to in [[all caps]] as INTERNET, despite not being an acronym.{{cite web|last1=Post|first1=David|title=The History of the Internet, Typography Division, Cont’d|url=http://volokh.com/2013/11/12/history-internet-typography-division-contd/|website=[[Volokh Conspiracy]]|accessdate=16 August 2015}} ==The Internet versus generic internets== The Internet standards community historically differentiated between ''the'' [[Internet]] and ''an'' [[internetworking|internet]] (or internetwork), treating the former as a [[proper noun]] with a capital letter, and the latter as a [[common noun]] with lower-case first letter. An internet is any internetwork or set of inter-connected [[Internet Protocol]] (IP) networks. The distinction is evident in [[Request for Comments]] documents from the early 1980s, when the transition from the ARPANET to the Internet was in progress, although it was not applied with complete uniformity.RFC 871 (1982) "The 'network' composed of the concatenation of such subnets is sometimes called 'a catenet,' though more often—and less picturesquely—merely 'an internet.{{'"}}RFC 872 (1982) "[TCP's] next most significant property is that it is designed to operate in a 'catenet' (also known as the, or an, 'internet')" Another example from that period is IBM's ''TCP/IP Tutorial and Technical Overview'' ({{ISBN|0-7384-2165-0}}) from 1989, which stated that:
The words internetwork and internet is {{sic}} simply a contraction of the phrase interconnected network. However, when written with a capital "I," the Internet refers to the worldwide set of interconnected networks. Hence, the Internet is an internet, but the reverse does not apply. The Internet is sometimes called the connected internet.
In the [[Request for Comments]] documents that define the evolving Internet Protocol standards, the term was introduced as a [[noun adjunct]], apparently a shortening of "internetworking"The form first occurring in the RFC series is "internetworking protocol", RFC 604: "Four of the reserved link numbers are hereby assigned for experimental use in the testing of an internetworking protocol." The first use of "internet" is in RFC 675, in the form "internet packet". and is mostly used in this way. As the [[wikt:impetus|impetus]] behind IP grew, it became more common to regard the results of internetworking as entities of their own, and ''internet'' became a noun, used both in a generic sense (any collection of computer networks connected through internetworking) and in a specific sense (the collection of computer networks that internetworked with ARPANET, and later [[National Science Foundation Network | NSFNET]], using the IP standards, and that grew into the connectivity service we know today). In its generic sense, ''internet'' is a common noun, a synonym for [[internetwork]]; therefore, it has a plural form (first appearing in the RFC series RFC 870, RFC 871 and RFC 872) and is not capitalized. In a [[Morris Worm|1991 court case]], Judge [[Jon O. Newman]] used it as a mass noun: "[[Robert Tappan Morris|Morris]] released the [[Morris worm|worm]] into INTERNET, which is a group of national networks that connect university, governmental, and military computers around the country." ==Argument for common noun usage== In 2002 a ''New York Times'' column said that ''Internet'' has been changing from a proper noun to a generic term.{{cite web|last=Schwartz |first=John |title=Who Owns the Internet? You and i Do |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/29/weekinreview/29SCHW.html |work=The New York Times |publisher= |date=29 December 2002 |accessdate=19 April 2009 |quote=Allan M. Siegal, a co-author of The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage and an assistant managing editor at the newspaper, said that 'there is some virtue in the theory' that Internet is becoming a generic term, 'and it would not be surprising to see the lowercase usage eclipse the uppercase within a few years.' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417131137/http://www.nytimes.com/2002/12/29/weekinreview/29SCHW.html |archivedate=17 April 2009 }} Words for new technologies, such as ''phonograph'' in the 19th century, are sometimes capitalized at first, later becoming uncapitalized. In 1999 another column said that ''Internet'' might, like some other commonly used proper nouns, lose its capital letter.{{cite news | first=Stephen | last=Wilbers | title=Errors put a wall between you and your readers | work=Orange County Register | location=Santa Ana, California | date=13 September 1999 | page=c.20 | quote=If you like being ahead of the game, you might prefer to spell internet and web as internet and web, but according to standard usage they should be capitalized. Keep in mind, however, that commonly used proper nouns sometimes lose their capital letters over time and that Internet and Web may someday go the way of the french fry. }} Capitalization of the word as an adjective also varies. Some guides specify that the word should be capitalized as a noun but not capitalized as an adjective, e.g., "internet resources".E.g. {{cite web|title=MIT Libraries House Style |url=http://libstaff.mit.edu/publications/housestyle.html |work=MIT Libraries Staff Web |publisher= |date=14 August 2008 |accessdate=19 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090426122506/http://libstaff.mit.edu/publications/housestyle.html |archivedate=26 April 2009 |df=dmy }} ==Argument for proper noun usage== According to English capitalization rules, all proper nouns should be capitalized.{{cite web|last1=Lukyanchuk|first1=Marina|title=Capitalization|url=https://www.grammarly.com/blog/capitalization-rules/|website=Grammarly.com|accessdate=8 February 2018}} Because there is only one global "Internet", when one speaks about the Internet itself, it should be capitalized. ==Usage examples== Examples of media publications and news outlets that capitalize the term include ''[[Time (magazine) | Time]]'', the [[United States Government Printing Office]],{{cite web | url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-STYLEMANUAL-2008/html/GPO-STYLEMANUAL-2008-6.htm | title = U.S. Government Printing Office Style Manual | publisher = [[United States Government Printing Office]] | accessdate = 24 April 2014 | quote = Internet, Intranet}} and ''[[The Times of India]]''. In addition, many [[peer review | peer-review]]ed journals and professional publications such as ''[[Communications of the ACM]]'' capitalize "Internet", and this style guideline is also specified by the [[American Psychological Association]] in its electronic media spelling guide. The [[Modern Language Association]]'s ''[[MLA Handbook]]'' does not specifically mention capitalization of Internet, but its consistent practice is to capitalize it.{{cite book | title = MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers | year = 2009 | publisher = Modern Language Association of America | location = New York | isbn = 9781603290241 | edition = Seventh}} A significant number of publications do not capitalize ''internet''. Among them are ''[[The Economist]]'', the ''[[Financial Times]]'', [[The Times|''The Times'' of London]], ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[The Observer]]'',{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/styleguide/i#id-3026449 | title = Guardian and Observer style guide | publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited | accessdate = 19 April 2008 | quote = internet, net, web, world wide web. See websites.}} the [[BBC]],{{cite web |url=http://www.wsscc.org/sites/default/files/publications/bbc_the_bbc_news_styleguide_2003.pdf |title=The BBC News Styleguide |accessdate=23 April 2014 |page=33 |quote=Viewers and listeners complain most loudly when they hear the wrong word used, and now scripts are widely available on the internet, misspellings, too, are public. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603235549/http://www.wsscc.org/sites/default/files/publications/bbc_the_bbc_news_styleguide_2003.pdf |archivedate=3 June 2013 |df=dmy }} and ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]''. As of 2011, most publications using "internet" appear to be located outside [[North America]], but the gap is closing. ''[[Wired News]]'', an American news source, adopted the lower-case spelling in 2004.{{cite web|last=Long |first=Tony |title=It's Just the 'internet' Now |url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2004/08/64596 |work=Wired |publisher= |date=16 August 2004 |accessdate=19 April 2009 |quote=... what the internet is: another medium for delivering and receiving information. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429065340/http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2004/08/64596 |archivedate=29 April 2009 |df=dmy }} Media companies like [[BuzzFeed]] and [[Vox Media]] avoid capitalizing the "internet" similarly. Around April 2010, [[CNN]] shifted its house style to adopt the lowercase spelling. The [[Associated Press]] announced that the 2016 ''[[AP Stylebook]]'' will no longer capitalize "internet".{{cite web | url = http://www.poynter.org/2016/ap-style-change-alert-dont-capitalize-internet-and-web-any-more/404664/ | title = AP Style alert: Don’t capitalize internet and web anymore | publisher = The Poynter Institute | access-date = 3 April 2016 | quote = The changes reflect a growing trend toward lowercasing both words, which have become generic terms }} ''[[The New York Times]]'' announced their decision in May 2016 to decapitalize all instances of "internet" for reasons similar to AP's.{{cite web | last = Bromwich | first = Jonah | date = May 24, 2016 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/25/business/media/internet-to-be-lowercase-in-new-york-times-and-associated-press.html | title = Bulletin! The 'Internet' Is About to Get Smaller | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 26 May 2016}} As Internet connectivity has expanded, it has started to be seen as a service similar to television, radio, and telephone, and the word has come to be used in this way (e.g. "I have the internet at home" and "I found it on the internet"). ==Regional differences== According to [[OxfordDictionaries.com|Oxford Dictionaries Online]], as of April 2016 the spelling ''Internet'' remains more usual in the US, while ''internet'' has become predominant in the UK.{{cite web| url=http://blog.oxforddictionaries.com/2016/04/should-you-capitalize-internet/ | title=Should you capitalize the word Internet? | publisher=[[OxfordDictionaries.com|Oxford Dictionaries Online]] | date=5 April 2016 | accessdate=9 April 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wiktionary|Internet}} *[http://www.chicagomanualofstyle.org/CMS_FAQ/InternetWebandOtherPost-WatergateConcerns/InternetWebandOtherPost-WatergateConcerns16.html Internet, Web, and Other Post-Watergate Concerns], The Chicago Manual of Style {{DEFAULTSORT:Internet capitalization conventions}} [[Category:Internet terminology]] [[Category:Capitalization]] [[Category:Linguistic controversies]] [[Category:Disputes in English grammar]]
