revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Dalmacio Iglesias García | image = Dalmacio Iglesias Garcia.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Dalmacio Iglesias García | birth_date = 1879 | birth_place = [[Santibáñez el Bajo]], Spain | death_date = 1933 | death_place = [[Barcelona]], Spain | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Jesús María José Dalmacio Iglesias García''' (1879-1933) was a [[Spanish people|Spanish]] [[Carlism|Carlist]] politician, active almost exclusively in [[Catalonia]]. His career climaxed during one term in the [[Congress of Deputies (Spain)|Congress of Deputies]] (1910-1914) and one term in the [[Senate of Spain|Senate]] (1918-1919). He did not manage to build his personal following; in historiography he is considered a rather unique case of a right-wing revolutionary who strove to launch a Christian, violent, urban, working class, anti-establishment movement. The bid has ultimately failed and in the 1920s Iglesias withdrew from active politics.
==Family and youth== [[File:Praza Maior, Ourense, 1900.jpg|thumb|left|Orense, around 1900]] The ancestors of Dalmacio Iglesias were related to [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]]. His paternal family originated from [[Orense]]; his grandfather, [[Victorio Iglesias Fernández]], served as oficial primero of Tesorería de Hacienda in the city.<ref>Xosé A. Fraga Vázquez, ''Luis Iglesias Pardo. Un especialista en Medicina naval'', [in:] ''Consello de Cultura Gallega'' service 02.05.14,, available [http://culturagalega.gal/albumdaciencia/imprimir-detalle.php?id=996 here]</ref> He married Vicenta Pardo<ref>see Iglesias' birth certifice, available at the official website of the Spanish senate [http://www.senado.es/cgi-bin/verdocweb?tipo_bd=HI20&PWIndice=6&Signatura=HIS-0229-07&Contenido=2 here] and a copy of birth certificate available [https://postimg.org/image/y0xj788wf/ here]</ref> and the couple had at least two sons; both of them studied medicine. The younger one, Luis Iglesias Pardo, served as physician in the Spanish navy; he gained some recognition in the maritime and local Galician realm as author of scientific works on medicine, sanitation and hygiene in the navy, all published in the 1870s and 1880s.<ref>for the list of Iglesias Pardo's works see Fraga Vázquez 2014</ref> The older brother, [[Antonio Iglesias Pardo]] (1844-1902),<ref>for birth date see Dalmacio's birth certificates referenced above; in 1879 his father was 35 years old. For death date see ''El Noroeste'' 08.02.02, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7116441&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> opted for a civilian career; in the 1870s he served in [[Cáceres, Spain|Cáceres]], but in 1885 he left [[Extremadura]]<ref>''Boletín oficial de la provincia de Cáceres'' 09.01.85, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000049184&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and returned to his native Orense. Until the mid-1890s he worked as surgeon in the city and in some neighboring locations, including these already in the [[Salamanca province]].<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 02.05.94, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7100319&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1898 he commenced practice in the [[Santiago de Compostela]] hospital,<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 23.06.98, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000258132&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> where he served until his premature death.<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 15.11.98, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000258250&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
At unspecified time though probably prior to mid-1870s Antonio Iglesias married María Asunción García Legond, a native of Santiago and member to another family related to military medical services.<ref>''Semanario Farmaceutico'' VI/24 (1878), available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0026910798&page=16 here]</ref> It is not clear how many children the couple had. Dalmacio was born during the Cáceres spell of his father, where he probably spent his childhood years. In the mid-1880s he moved with his parents to Orense, living at calle Cervantes 15.<ref>''Boletín oficial de la provincia de Orense'' 30.11.94, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1115773&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> It is there where in the local Insituto – the secular secondary school – he was rewarded with high grades upon his bachillerato.<ref>''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref> At unspecified time yet most likely in the late 1890s he enrolled at the faculty of law at [[Universidad de Santiago]], where his career was punctuated by a brief period of military service.<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 31.08.98, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000258187&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> As a university student he performed brilliantly; Iglesias obtained governmental prize in course of the curriculum, was rewarded for his study on legal rights of married woman and got premio etraordinario when graduated in 1902.<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 01.10.02, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000259101&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Erasmo de Janer.jpg|thumb|160px|[[Erasmo Janer Gironella|Erasmo Janer]]]] Upon passing entry exams in early 1903 Iglesias was admitted to [[:es:Ministerio de Hacienda y Administraciones Públicas|Ministerio de Hacienda]]<ref>''Diario de Burgos'' 09.02.03, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000435461&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here], and ''El Eco de Santiago'' 29.04.03, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000259568&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and moved to [[Madrid]],<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 06.11.03, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000259723&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> soon to be placed as the ministry delegate in [[Barcelona]]. In ciudad condal in 1907<ref>''El Tradicionalista'' 16.06.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1009284&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he married Mercedes Janer Milá de la Roca (died 1963),<ref>''Hoja oficial de la provincia de Barcelona'' 29.04.83, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000225063&interno=S&posicion=8&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> daughter to a Catalan Carlist leader and wealthy entrepreneur [[:es:José Erasmo de Janer y de Gironella|José Erasmo Janer Gironella]].<ref>for genealogical tree of the Janer family see Gary Wray McDonogh, ''Good Families of Barcelona: A Social History of Power in the Industrial Era'', Princeton 2014, {{ISBN|9781400858231}}, p. 160</ref> Dalmacio and Mercedes settled in the Catalan capital.<ref>Javier Pérez-Roldán Suanzes-Carpegna, ''Janer y Milá de la Roca (María de los Ángeles de)'', [in:] ''Tradición Viva'' service 05.10.15, available [http://www.tradicionviva.es/2015/10/05/janer-y-mila-de-la-roca-maria-de-los-angeles-de/ here]</ref> None of their descendants became a publicly recognized figure. They had one child, María de las Mercedes, who married a navy officer Federico Caso Montaner.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 19.10.35, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/04/05/pagina-8/33145356/pdf.html here]</ref> Dalmacio Iglesias did not live to see his only grandson, Alberto Caso Iglesias,<ref>born 1935, died 2015; for date of birth see ''La Vanguardia'' 19.10.35, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/04/05/pagina-8/33145356/pdf.html here], for date of death see ''Albert María Caso Iglesias'' entry, [in:] ''Capgros'' service, available [http://www.capgros.com/necrologiques/alberto-maria-caso-iglesias_613221_102.html# here]</ref> who would later become a physician.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 20.10.60, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1960/10/20/pagina-22/32727001/pdf.html here]</ref> Dalmacio's sister-in-law María gained name as a Carlist propagandist and activist,<ref>Pérez-Roldán Suanzes-Carpegna 2015</ref> while his brother-in-law [[:ca:Ignasi de Janer i Milà de la Roca|Ignacio]] became a locally known writer. Cousins of his wife [[:ca:Erasme de Lasarte i de Janer|Erasme]] and [[:ca:Josep Maria de Lasarte i de Janer|José Lasarte Janer]] turned recognized Catalan artists, respectively a painter and a writer. It is not clear whether a well-known singer [[Julio Iglesias]], who also originated from Orense, was his distant relative.<ref>Julio Iglesias' paternal grandfather, Ulpiano Iglesias Sarria (born in Orense in 1877), was a military and a pharmacist. No information on Iglesias Sarria's ancerstors is readily available</ref>
==Early public activity (before 1910)== [[File:Redacción de Gaceta de Galicia 1904.jpg|thumb|left|''[[:es:Gaceta de Galicia|Gaceta de Galicia]]'' editorial borad, around 1904 (Iglesias not present)]] The young Dalmacio has early developed a penchant for letters and already in 1893 he contributed to local periodicals.<ref>the local Galician dailies that Iglesias contributed to were ''El Eco de Orense, La Voz Católica, El Derecho'' and ''La Nueva Epoca''; the weekly was ''La Bruja''; all this information has been provided by Iglesias himself, ''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref> During his academic period he kept publishing<ref>''El Noroeste, La Gaceta de Galicia'' and ''El Pensamiento Gallego'', ''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref> and founded an ephemeral literary weekly ''Santiago''. He practiced his oratory skills in Ateneo Escolar Compostelano, where he became first the secretary and then the president, and in Ateneo Leon XIII.<ref>''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref> Inclined towards literature, he used to read out his own poetry<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 10.12.97, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000258565&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here], also ''El Eco de Santiago'' 09.12.01, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000259455&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and wrote prosaic pieces in [[Galician language|Gallego]],<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 24.02.98, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000258035&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> his works were flavored with militant religious zeal. In 1902 he took part in the Catholic Congress in Santiago and presented a paper at a section dedicated to religious orders.<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 14.07.02, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000259037&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> It was during the academic period when Iglesias was fascinated by the personality of [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]] and got attracted to Carlism.<ref>''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref>
It seems that upon arrival in Catalonia Iglesias engaged in Carlist youth structures; in 1904 he was noted as giving lectures in Círculo Tradicionalista of Barcelona<ref>''El Eco de Santiago'' 17.10.94, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000260883&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and in late 1905 he became vice-president of Juventud Tradicionalista in the city,<ref>''El Tradicionalista'' 04.11.05, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1009587&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> delivering addresses also elsewhere in Catalonia, e.g. in [[Gerona, Spain|Gerona]].<ref>''El Norte'' 10.12.16, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3066121&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> At the time the Catalan Carlists were more than ever prepared to swallow their skepticism about alliance with other anti-governmental parties, especially the regionalists from [[Regionalist League of Catalonia|La Lliga]]; the strategy produced a broad electoral alliance known as [[Catalan Solidarity (1906)|Solidaridad Catalana]]. Iglesias spoke vehemently against this "hermandad vulgo pisto rabioso pactada"; his highly emotional harangues earned him attention of the [[Liberalism in Spain|Liberal]] and [[Republicanism in Spain|Republican]] press, as already in early 1906 he featured as a negative point of reference.<ref>''La Lucha'' 02.03.06, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1077997&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Apart from his duties as a Ministry of Finance delegate Iglesias practiced also as a lawyer.<ref>''El Tradicionalista'' 16.06.07, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1009284&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1908 he got involved in a controversial and widely discussed case known as "caso Rull". Rull was an undercover police operative who penetrated the world of Barcelona proletarian conspiracy but was himself charged with terrorism, perhaps related to some extreme party or organization.<ref>the explosives that Rull was associated with were planted in obscure and unfrequented passages apparently with little harm intended, which led some to suspect he was on service of an unidentified extreme party aiming at bringing police forces into disrepute, compare ''El Pais'' 09.04.08, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002325258&page=2 here], see also Eduardo González Calleja, ''La razón de la fuerza: orden público, subversión y violencia política en la España de la Restauración (1875–1917)'', Madrid 1998, {{ISBN|9788400077785}}, p. 401</ref> Iglesias first represented some of the defendants in court<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 26.03.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7119285&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and later defended Rull himself in an appeal case.<ref>''El Bien Público'' 25.04.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000138325&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The two seemed to have developed sort of friendship yet the prosecutor had his way and Rull was eventually executed;<ref>''Los Debates'' 10.08.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1045667&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> during and after the affair Iglesias was widely quoted speaking on terrorism and related issues.<ref>''La Correspondencia de Valencia'' 27.05.08, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000239277&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> The Rull affair gained Iglesias a name in Barcelona, since in 1909 he emerged as expert on "antrolopología criminal".<ref>''La Bandera Regional' 27.11.09, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000373158&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Semana Trágica en Barcelona.jpg|thumb|burning churches during [[Tragic Week (Catalonia)|Semana Tragica]], [[Barcelona]] 1909]] Once the city was rocked by riots known as [[Tragic Week (Catalonia)|Semana Trágica]] Iglesias voiced against "doctrinas positivistas" and secular teaching, identified as primary roots of urban unrest.<ref>''La Bandera Ragional'' 27.11.09, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000373158&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In 1909 and in response to left-wing violence Iglesias engaged in Catholic social action<ref>''El Social'' 03.04.09, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2098864&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and was among the founders of Carlism-related Comité de Defensa Social,<ref>''Las Provincias'' 26.11.09, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000315040&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> an hybrid organisation with characteristics of a cultural centre, a mutual help organization, a militia and a trade union. As a joint CdDS and Carlist representative<ref>''El Norte'' 19.04.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3066548&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> supported by other right-wing groupings<ref>Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 134</ref> he ran in the [[Spanish general election, 1910|Cortes elections]] from Gerona in 1910; riding the wave of anti-Left backlash which followed The Tragic Week he somewhat unexpectedly emerged triumphant.<ref>in 1910 Iglesias received 2,957 votes out of 8,653 votes cast and 11,344 voters entitled, compare the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2855870%29.NDIP. here] Iglesias defeated a Republican Eduardo Fernández del Pozo and liberals, Jaime Roura and Pablo Bosch y Barrau</ref>
==Political climax (1910-1914)== [[File:TTV.87.11.jpg|thumb|left|Catalan [[requetés]], 1910s]] The 1910-1914 Cortes service proved the period of Iglesias' hectic if not frenetic activity, especially during the first two years of his tenure.<ref>between June and December of 1910 Iglesias was noted at least 750 times in the press. In 1911 he was mentioned around 600 times, in 1912 around 450 times, in 1913 around 170 times and in 1914 around 110 times, compare ''prensahistorica'' service, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/estaticos/contenido.cmd?pagina=estaticos/presentacion here], and ''hemerotecadigital'' service, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/index.vm here]</ref> Though he focused also on topics like the army<ref>''Diario de Tortosa'' 27.10.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1032274&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and economy<ref>''La Tarde'' 30.11.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1116667&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he was mostly bent on confronting the [[Radical Republican Party|Radicals]] of [[Alejandro Lerroux|Lerroux]], whom he presented as a threat not only to public order but also to the entire civilization.<ref>e.g. in July 1910 Iglesias demanded that all lerrouxista centres in Barcelona are closed as threat to public order, ''La Defensa'' 04.07.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1143662&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], and blamed the lerrouxistas fpr Semana Trágica, ''El Noticiero'' 07.07.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2044497&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. Many times he clashed with Radicals in the Cortes, compare ''Las Provincias'' 07.07.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000313267&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], including oral skirmishes with Lerroux himself, ''El Eco de Navarra'' 08.06.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=6005259&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> His own rhetoric was inflammatory; [[José Canalejas (politician)|Canalejas]] noted that in his counter-revolutionary zeal he was carried away by hysteria.<ref>Canalejas noted Iglesias' promise that he would "iba a matar la hidra revolucionaria con la punta de su espada", ''La Juventud'' 03.09.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000431005&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]. In revenge Iglesias denounced Canalejas as a masonic tool of the English, ''El Clamor'' 08.04.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2245549&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. His claims about the English and the freemasonry made some impact in the Vatican diplomacy, Ramon Corts i Blay, ''La Setmana Tràgica de 1909: l'Arxiu Secret Vaticà'', Montserrat 2009, {{ISBN|9788498831443}}, p. 156</ref> Though member of the diet, Iglesias emerged as leader of right-wing Catalan obrerismo, a working class violent anti-establishment movement.<ref>it is not clear how Iglesias' militant obrerismo translated into his parliamentary activity. In 1912 he proposed a draft law on "passive classes", yet no details are available, compare ''La Atalaya'' 09.03.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000394030&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. He was also in favor of regulations which legitimized strike action, ''La Región Cantabra'' 26.10.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000425846&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Confronting both radical lerrouxistas and bourgeoisie La Lliga, Iglesias started to champion what looked like a nascent Christian, urban, aggressive, proletariant protest crusade.<ref>Iglesias is considered "clearest example" of the fact that radical Carlists "dropped their usual conterrevolutionary guise, revealing a Carlist potential to evolve toward eplicitly right revolutionary positions", Colin. M. Winston, ''Carlist workers groups in Catalonia, 1900-1923'', [in:] Stanley G. Payne (ed.), ''Identidad y nacionalismo en la España contemporánea: el carlismo, 1833-1975'', Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8487863469}}, p. 91</ref> His zeal to do away with the regime would soon lead him to advancing theories of Carlists and republicans joining ranks to topple the [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] system,<ref>''El Progreso'' 09.12.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5068525&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> quickly quashed by the party hierarchy<ref>Collin Winston, ''The Proletarian Carlist Road to Fascism: Sindicalismo Libre'', [in:] ''Journal of Contemporary History'' 17 (1982), p. 561</ref> and rejected by the Republicans.<ref>''El Progreso'' 09.12.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5068525&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Iglesias's name soon became tantamount to an explosive conflict. Due to violent language employed and logic which instigated rebellion his press articles gave rise to many official enquiries.<ref>see e.g. ''El Radical'' 26.06.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2140240&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], ''Las Provincias'' 04.01.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000310745&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagin here], ''El Grano de Arena'' 03.02.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3002744&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here], ''El Cantabrico'' 23.02.13, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000409444&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], ''Las Provincias'' 06.11.13, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000315354&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In the early 1910s he managed himself two weeklies: ''La Voz de la Tradición''<ref>José Navarro Cabanes, ''Apuntes bibliográficos de la prensa carlista'', Valencia 1917, pp. 252-253</ref> and ''La Trinchera'';<ref>''La Correspondencia de Valencia'' 13.05.13, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000240839&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> especially the latter emerged as the chief platform of violent obrerista propaganda<ref>Winston 2001, p. 88</ref> which indulged in "fantasies of civil war in which Carlism triumphed".<ref>Winston 2001, p. 90</ref> Police prevented sale of his discourses<ref>''El Salmantino'' 03.08.10, availavle [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5038736&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and he was among the most investigated MPs, by far surpassing the first ever [[PSOE|socialist]] MP in the Spanish parliament, [[Pablo Iglesias Posse|Pablo Iglesias]].<ref>in 1912 he was the 5th most interrogated deputy in the Cortes, with 46 cases against him, ''La Información'' 28.02.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2126854&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Almost every second rally Iglesias attended ended up in riots, usually between the Carlist [[requetés]] and the Radical Jovenes Barbaros.<ref>some of his pamphlets might have triggered violence, compare ''La Correspondencia de España'' 03.08.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7121584&interno=S&posicion=7&presentacion=pagina here]. Clashes were not limited to Catalonia, as they occurred even when he did show up in his native Orense, ''El Progreso'' 26.10.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3096571&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. Some incidents were clearly provoked by Iglesias, e.g. when leading a group of requetés he used to interrupt movie showings or assaulted orchestra playing ''La Marseillaise'', ''El Adelanto'' 26.05.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7500122&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]; 1911 his Blona meeting and discourse on pornography ended up – as usual – in skirmishes, ''El Cantábrico'' 22.05.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000408807&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]. As a result, the lerrouxistas awaited him to stage their own provocations, ''La Correspondencia de Alicante'' 02.10.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=4008233&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]. The list of clashes, skirmishes or riots related to him as listed in the press would cover tens of incidents</ref> Even his expected attendance might have led to violent clashes, e.g. with two dead left in [[Eibar]].<ref>''El Noticiero'' 08.04.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2042671&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He was a few times assaulted.<ref>e.g. in Caraselva Iglesias was assaulted on the street, see ''El Salmantino'' 21.09.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5040571&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. In 1911 a train he was travelling at was shoot at, or at least it was believed so, ''El Noroeste'' 13.09.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7106505&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> However, the most deadly turned out to be a [[:ca:Enfrontament entre carlins i lerrouxistes de Sant Feliu de Llobregat|1911 urban battle in Sant Feliu de Llobregat]]; following his address at a Carlist rally hundreds of requetés and lerrouxistas engaged in a melee which left 6 people killed,<ref>''El Restaurador'' 02.06.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1014188&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the incident investigated later in the parliament. It is with his personal contribution that "from 1911 to 1916 scuffling and occasional shoot-outs between Carlist and Radical youth were an accepted part of the Barcelona scene",<ref>Winston 1982, p. 560, Winston 2001, p. 90</ref> especially that in 1913 he hailed "the club and the browning, the two indispensable companions of Jaimist youth".<ref>Winston 1982, pp. 560, 561. Iglesias intended to build requeté as shock troops used in a revolutionary insurgence which was expected to topple the republic, González Calleja 1998, p. 494</ref> [[File:Els morts a Sant Feliu 1911.jpg|thumb|victims of [[:ca:Enfrontament entre carlins i lerrouxistes de Sant Feliu de Llobregat|Sant Feliu clashes]], 1911]] Iglesias' radicalism estranged the Catalan Carlist leadership and the regional party jefe [[Manuel de Llanza y Pignatelli|Duque de Solferino]] a few times tried to mitigate him;<ref>Eduardo González Calleja, ''Paramilitarització i violencia politica a l'Espanya del primer terc de segle: el requeté tradicionalista (1900-1936)'', [in:] ''Revista de Girona'' 37 (1991), p. 70</ref> despite being Gerona MP Iglesias did not head the provincial Gerona organisation.<ref>the provincial Carlist Gerona jefe was José María Vilahur, Albert Balcells, Joan B. Culla, Conxita Mir, ''Les eleccions generals a Catalunya de 1901 a 1923'', Barcelona 1982, p. 222</ref> Iglesias himself started to dream of old-fashioned party leaders killed in a civil war and making room for the youth.<ref>Winston 2001, p. 90</ref> However, in 1912 he entered the national Carlist executive<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis UNED], Madrid 2012, p. 458</ref> and also in 1912 in [[Biarritz]] he met [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|his king]] for the first time.<ref>''Diario de Córdoba'' 10.05.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5000582&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]. He claimed he had not known Don Jaime before, see ''El Porvenir'' 02.07.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2151733&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here], though one year earlier, in September 1911, he had been reported as departing to Frohsdor to speak with Don Jaime on organization of Carlism, ''La Atalaya'' 24.09.11, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000393864&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]. Iglesias' stand versus Don Jaime is not clear. On the one hand it does not seem marked by particular loyalty; upon his 1910 election he refused to send a customary Carlist telegram message of adhesion and claimed he had to wait for approval from Comité de Defensa Social, ''La Correspondencia de España'' 14.04.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7124409&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]. On the other hand, in June 1912 Iglesias felt competent to discuss Don Jaime's private issues and declare that he would soon marry a foregin princess, ''La Atalaya'' 01.06.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000394112&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He did not seem engaged in struggle for power within the party top echelons and is not listed as protagonist of a raging conflict between his old-time master Vázquez de Mella and the official party leader, [[:es:Bartolomé Feliu|Bartolomé Feliu]].<ref>the most detailed work on Carlist history at the turn of the centuries, Fernández Escudero 2012, barely mentions Iglesias. A work on Mellismo does not mention Iglesias prior to the Great War period, see Andres Martin 2000</ref>
==On the verge of loyalty (1914-1919)== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumb|left|Carlist standard]] In the [[Spanish general election, 1914|1914 electoral campaign]] Iglesias stood as a Carlist candidate in Gerona<ref>in 1910 a Republican daily claimed that Gerona was "feudo de don Dalmacio Iglesias" and agonised about his inquisitorial methods against the Liberals, ''El Pueblo'' 21.07.10, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1149488&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here], but given his 1914 defeat the claims seem exaggerated or outdated</ref> and though proportionally he was more successful than 4 years earlier, ultimately he failed to renew his deputy ticket.<ref>in 1910 Iglesias gained 2.957 votes (34,15% of voters and 26,06% of those entitled to vote). In 1914 he gained 2,954 votes (respectively 36,31% and 26,5%) and lost to a Republican contender, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, pp. 546, 534</ref> It would soon turn out that he failed in his later bids – also from Gerona - of 1916<ref>in 1916 Iglesias gained 2,465 votes (29,81% of the voters and 21,39% of the electorate) and lost to a Republican contender, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 559</ref> and 1918.<ref>in 1918 Iglesias gained 2,241 votes (25,98% of the voters and 19,26% of the electorate) and lost to a Lliguero contende, Balcells, Culla, Mir 1982, p. 570</ref> Iglesias acknowledged defeat, resumed his suspended duties as Hacienda delegate and re-opened the law office in Barcelona.<ref>''Heraldo de Gerona'' 15.06.14, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1085073&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]. He was member of colegios in Barcelona, Lleida and Tarragona, ''Heraldo Alaves'' 01.12.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2289231&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Always skeptical about courting La Lliga, in the mid-1910s Iglesias started to lead an anti-Catalanist group within the local party. Though he declared himself a regionalist and even in favor of autonomy,<ref>''El Porvenir'' 07.06.12, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2151733&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> by scholars he is considered a champion of anti-regionalist españolismo;<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 134</ref> opponent of the new Catalan Carlist leader [[:es:Miguel Junyent|Miguel Junyent]]<ref>in January 1915 Iglesias was still recorded as speaking with Junyent during the same rally, ''El Porvenir'' 14.01.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2151816&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and his daily ''El Correo Catalan'', Iglesias openly challenged his line of seeking understanding with the [[Catalanism|Catalanists]]. The rift became clear when in 1915 he founded ''El Legitimista Catalan'';<ref>''La Correponsencia de España'' 02.05.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7135081&interno=S&posicion=7&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the national party jefe [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|Cerralbo]] disauthorised the paper<ref>''La Correpospondencia de Valencia'' 12.06.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000241539&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here], ''Montejurra'' 50 (1970), p. VIII</ref> and threatened these taking part in a related meeting with expulsion;<ref>''El Cantabrico'' 13.06.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000410258&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> the meeting took place and invariably ended in riots,<ref>''La Correspondencia de Valencia'' 13.06.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000241540&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> but the weekly was eventually closed after just 3 months.<ref>''El Legitimista'' was issued between October 1915 and December 1915, Jaime del Burgo, ''Bibliografia del Siglo XIX'', Pamplona 1978, {{ISBN|8423503429}}, p. 570</ref> Iglesias found himself on the verge of loyalty to the party, yet Cerralbo<ref>perhaps influenced by de Mella, as some scholars suggest that during his second tenure de Cerralbo was a front-man with de Mella actually running the party, compare Fernández Escudero 2012</ref> preferred not to escalate the conflict; in 1916 he confirmed Iglesias as the party candidate from Gerona,<ref>''El Cantabrico'' 26.03.16, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000410545&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> which in turn triggered protest resignation of the local Carlist Junta Provincial.<ref>Conxita Mir, ''Lleida (1890-1936): caciquisme polític i lluita electoral'', Montserrat 1985, {{ISBN|9788472027169}}, p. 311</ref> Iglesias kept lambasting a policy which according to him melted Carlism in a broad Catalanism;<ref>''El Debate'' 28.03.64, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2282956&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> upon the 1917 emergence of [[:es:Asamblea de Parlamentarios|Parliamentary Assembly]]<ref>the Assembly was attended by some fellow Gerona Carlists like Pedro Llosas Badía</ref> he strongly voiced against the initiative<ref>''El Adelanto'' 02.08.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7506585&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> as giving in to the likes of Lerroux and [[Cambó]].<ref>''El Porvenir'' 09.08.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2151794&interno=S&presentacion=pagina&posicion=1 here]</ref> {{CSS image crop |Image = Dalmacio Iglesias.png |bSize = 160 |cWidth = 160 |cHeight = 260 |oTop = 0 |oLeft = 0 |Location = right |Description = Iglesias as senator, 1918 }} There were two other threads which rendered Iglesias a key protagonist of internal conflict in regional Carlism. One was his continued penchant for social radicalism; he remained active in Comité de Defensa Social and even built its militia,<ref>''La Esquella de la Torratxa'' 03.03.16, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=4034836&interno=S&posicion=28&presentacion=pagina here]. In early 1919 Iglesias was Inspector General de Requeté de Catalunya, ''El Norte'' 07.02.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3066170&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> apart from reverting to a theory that the Carlists should close ranks with "extrema izquierda" in order to do away with the corrupted regime.<ref>''El Gironés'' 15.04.16, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3064182&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Another conflictive issue was the Great War. While the party officially supported neutrality most Catalan Carlists harbored [[francophone]] feelings; Iglesias emerged as leader of the local pro-German faction, noted for his cries of ''viva Alemania''<ref>''El Noroeste'' 02.08.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7107955&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and even for declaration that he was prepared to shed blood if the time comes.<ref>''La Correspondencia de España'' 27.06.15, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=7135137&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]; the English have been traditionally considered the enemies of Spain and other nations, compare [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]</ref>
It remains paradoxical that despite his extremely conflictive personality Iglesias remained on at least formally correct terms with other party leaders; in 1917 together with Junyent he entered Comité de Acción Política of the Catalan Carlism,<ref>contrary to usual opinions of Iglesias as anti-Catalanist españolista, he supported the concept that internal Carlist Catalan documents be written in Catalan, ''El Norte'' 30.12.17, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3064401&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> a new body of somewhat unclear role.<ref>in early 1918 the Comité personal setup seems to have changed; Solferino and Junyent disappeared, while Teodoro Más emerged as president and Iglesias is secretary, which might be indicative of the body taken over by the Mellistas, ''El Norte'' 05.01.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3065675&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> It seems even more surprising that following defeat in 1918 elections Iglesias managed to ensure support of conservative parties when competing for seat in the Senate from [[Tarragona]]; it seems that he owed success<ref>''La Cruz'' 12.03.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3048662&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> to [[Antonio Maura|Maura]] and his ruling faction rather than to his own party.<ref>it seems that Iglesias got was running for senate as the official governmental candidate, Isidre Molas, ''Els senadors carlins de Catalunya'', Barcelona 2009, p. 17</ref> During a short term between mid-1918 and mid-1919 he basked in prestige of a senator and contributed to a few legal solutions adopted, e.g. to the law on civil servants.<ref>''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref>
==In search of a new political identity (1919-1923)== [[File:Jaime de Borbón, in El Mundo Grafico 7 10 1931 página 24.jpg|thumb|160px|left|[[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], around 1919]] Conflict between the key party theorist Vázquez de Mella and the claimant [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Don Jaime]], the strife which was tearing Carlism apart since the late 1900s, came to an abrupt end in early 1919: the [[Mellismo|Mellistas]] broke away to build their own party. Iglesias has always remained fascinated with de Mella yet he did not count among his partisans in course of internal conflict;<ref>compare Fernandez Escudero 2012, Andres Martin 2000</ref> it was only during the [[First world war|Great War]] that he emerged as key Catalan Mellista. In February 1919 he was expulsed from Comunión Tradicionalista<ref>''El Cantábrico'' 04.02.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000411579&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and immediately engaged in work to built a new Mellista organization. After [[:es:Teodoro de Mas y Nadal|Teodoro Más]], leader of the Catalan secessionists,<ref>''La Opinión'' 28.09.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1157430&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Iglesias was the most prominent exponent of the breakaways in the region and some count him among the most prominent secessionists also nationwide;<ref>in 1919 he was considered one of key promellistas with [[Victor Pradera Larumbe|Pradera]], Garcia Guijarro, [[Jaime Chicharro Sánchez-Guió|Chicharro]], Careaga and [[José Pascual de Liñán y Eguizábal|Doña Marina]]; in February 1919 they united in senate and declared themselves anti-Jaimistas, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 147</ref> some authors name him a leader of "dalmacistas", one of a few mostly personalist factions allegedly making up the Mellista group.<ref>according to a Jaimista author in early 1919 the Mellistas were nothing but a bunch of personalist following groups like "doñamarinistas, dalmacistas, o chicharristas", Andrés Martín 2000, p. 162. However other authors suggest that at this point Iglesias parted ways with the radical Barcelona Carlists. Though earlier he was their most recognizable personality, in 1919 most of them remained loyal to Don Jaime, Colin Winston, ''Workers and the Right in Spain'', Princeton 2014, {{ISBN|9781400858095}}, pp. 157-158</ref>
Upon expiration of the senator mandate in May 1919 Iglesias for the 5th time tried to obtain the deputy ticket from Gerona and for the 4th time failed;<ref>when running from Gerona Iglesias got 2241 votes, ''El Norte'' 13.05.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3066421&interno=S&posicion=2&presentacion=pagina here], which amounts to 31,6% of the voters and 20,0% of the electorate, see the official Cortes service [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDBuscHisDip?_piref73_1340033_73_1340032_1340032.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXDSP.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%40ELEN%26gt%3B%3D%2250%22+%26+%40ELEN%26lt%3B%3D%2250%22+%26+%28%22GERONA%22%29.DIST. here]</ref> initially reported to run for a consolation prize in the senate from Tarragona<ref>''El Restaurador'' 10.05.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1009791&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he eventually withdrew.<ref>''El Eco de la Comarca'' 22.06.19, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1025148&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> He contributed to local efforts of forging a new party within a grand right-wing coalition and specified his program as "religión, unidad de la Patria española, Orden social y Monarquía tradicional y, por tanto, regionalista";<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 172, ''ABC'' 18.05.19</ref> indeed he supported the autonomous statute drafted by [[Commonwealth of Catalonia|Mancomunitat]].<ref>Albert Balcells, ''El projecte d'autonomia de la Mancomunitat de Catalunya del 1919 i el seu context històric'', Barcelona 2010, p. 94. In 1919 in front of Mancomunitat Iglesias defended the right of castellano-speaking children to education in castellano, Balcells 2010, p. 245</ref> During a grand assembly of Catalan Mellistas in Badalona of 1920 he hoped they would serve as agglutinatory factor for all Catholic forces,<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 197-198</ref> yet such a union was slow to materialize: in 1921 he was denied the Maurista support during one more bid for the senate.<ref>during the 1921 electoral campaign Iglesias was reportedly denied supported of the Mauristas, which he considered treason, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 213</ref> As usual his appearances led to unrest, though in 1921 his rally was interrupted by his former darlings requetés, who shouted "viva Jaime Tercero".<ref>''El Noticiero Gaditano'' 04.06.21, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2064494&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> [[File:Mella en Barcelona 1921.png|thumb|[[Mellismo|Mellista]] meeting, Barcelona 1921]] In mid-1922 Iglesias was still reported as heart and soul of the new emerging Mellista party and seemed prepared to go to great lengths when seeking allies, most likely the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]]; he admitted that having broken all ties with Don Jaime, he was prepared to recognize [[Alfonso XIII of Spain|Don Alfonso]] as a legitimate king given he swears allegiance to the [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] principles.<ref>''El Debate'' 19.06.22, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2284163&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here], Andres Martin 2000, p. 230</ref> However, at some point he apparently lost any hope about the Mellista project. Tempted by [[:es:Partido Social Popular|Partido Social Popular]] of [[Salvador Minguijón Adrián|Salvador Minguijón]] and other breakaway Carlists, he considered it a would-be embodiment of "sumarse al partido católico" plan.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 233</ref> Eventually he neared an initiative to launch a non-dynastical monarchist party, though still remained cautious that the Traditionalists should not lose their own identity. In late 1922 Iglesias was missing among participants of overdue Mellista party launch in [[Zaragoza]]<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 237-239</ref> and joined Unión Monárquica Nacional instead.<ref>Molas 2009, p. 20</ref> In 1923 he was once again rumored to run – as independent – for deputy ticket from Gerona.<ref>''La Opinión'' 23.04.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1053101&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> His political bewilderment was eventually terminated by the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera y Sáenz de Heredia|Primo de Rivera]] coup and ban on all party activity.
==Primoderiverista and afterwards (1923-1933)== [[File:Gobierno-primorivera.jpg|thumb|left|Directorio, 1925]] Iglesias had no doubt about adhering to the new regime. Already in late 1923 he took part in homage feasts celebrating Primo as savior of the fatherland;<ref>''Diario de Valencia'' 21.11.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000192953&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]; himself as self-proclaimed representative of Catalan people together with other Barcelona personalities he presented the dictator with a historical sword, ''Diario de Burgos'', 03.12.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000441807&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> explicitly exalting "golpe de estado" he offered his services to the military directorio.<ref>''El Diario Palentino'' 03.12.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2213415&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> During a 1924 rally of Juventud de Acción Tradicionalista<ref>''El Noticiero Gaditano'' 15.07.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2058286&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> he hailed the coup as doing away with the old regime and as a deed spirited by traditionalist principles.<ref>''La Rioja'' 17.07.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3079545&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]</ref>
Exact scale of Iglesias' engagement in the primoderiverista regime is not clear. He later claimed that during personal meetings with the dictator he had tried to impose upon Primo his own social concerns and that he had repeatedly suggested that the regime should lower the cost of life for the middle- and working class.<ref>''La Voz de Aragón'' 21.05.30, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000377246&interno=S&posicion=8&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Press information confirms only his meetings with the Catalan [[:ca:emilio barrera|capitán general]], yet their purpose was not revealed.<ref>''La Atalaya'' 19.12.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000398348&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Active in [[Patriotic Union (Spain)|Union Patriotica]],<ref>''Hoja Oficial de la Provincia de Barcelona'' 21.05.28, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000223253&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here], for 1929 see also ''Hoja Oficial de la Provincia de Barcelona'' 09.09.28, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000223321&interno=S&posicion=5&presentacion=pagina here], Winston 2014, p. 243</ref> in the late 1920s he seemed less enthusiastic about the dictatorial regime and criticized the constitution draft as the one which reproduced most defects of the [[Spanish Constitution of 1876|1876 document]];<ref>''Nuevo Día'' 24.07.29, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000040046&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> in his 1930 pamphlet, ''Política de la dictadura'', Iglesias charged Primo with giving in to capitalist pressure and abandoning the cause of the working people;<ref>''La Voz de Aragón'' 21.05.30, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000377246&interno=S&posicion=8&presentacion=pagina here], Shlomó Ben-Amí, ''Fascism from above: the dictatorship of Primo de Rivera in Spain, 1923-1930'', New York 1983, {{ISBN|9780198225966}}, pp. 307-308</ref> another pamphlet read like an offer to a centre-left political party.<ref>Dalmacio Iglesias, ''La carestía de la vida: sus causas y sus remedios. Programa económico para cualquier partido político'' (1930)</ref>
In private Iglesias was confirmed at his job of Ministry of Finance delegate to Catalonia; his career was not ruined even by a fistfight with another official over his allegedly unsubstantiated absence in the office, perhaps the last manifestation of Iglesias' notorious inflammatory personality.<ref>''La Gaceta de Tenerife'' 31.10.23, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=5042566&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> In mid-1920s he competed for position of Jefe de la sección de Hacienda<ref>''Diario de Valencia'' 05.01.26, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000192243&interno=S&posicion=8&presentacion=pagina here]; according to an encyclopaedia note in 1920 he was nominated "jefe de negociado de Hacienda, ''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 939</ref> and in 1927 he was promoted to Jefé Superior de Administración Civil in Catalonia.<ref>''La Cruz'' 08.10.27, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3053130&interno=S&posicion=3&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> At that time he emerged as expert on canon law and author of a few related works,<ref>''La Palanca'' 24.09.18, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=2161338&interno=S&posicion=4&presentacion=pagina here]. Iglesias juridical works published were ''Existencia legal de las Órdenes religosas en España'' (1902), ''Capacidad jurídica de la mujer casada ante el derecho natural'' (1906), ''Nociones de administración y contabilidad de la Hacienda pública'' (1906), ''Educación y dirección de las nuevas multitudes'' (1909), ''Oposiciones al cuerpo de aspirantes a la judicatura y ministerio fiscal: contestación a las preguntas relativas a derecho civil'' (with José Morell y Terry, 1915) and ''Instituciones de Derecho eclesiástico con arreglo al nuevo Código del Derecho canónico'' (1918)</ref> which probably earned him Cruz de Oro of [[Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice]] order, awarded by the pope.<ref>''La Reconquista'' 17.07.20, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1015342&interno=S&posicion=1&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> Indeed, in the late 1920s he was noted in public mostly as engaged in numerous religious activities.<ref>''Hoja Oficial de la Provincia de Barcelona'' 08.02.26, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000223134&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here], see also ''La Vanguardia'' 11.01.30, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1929/03/09/pagina-10/33211873/pdf.html here]</ref> As expert in juridical science he edited a number of entries in ''Enciclopedia Espasa'', including the one on himself.<ref>''Enciclopedia Universal Ilustrada Europeo-Americana'', vol. 28, part I, Madrid 1925, p. 940</ref> Last but not least, he was not missing during the 1928 funeral of his old-time master Vázquez de Mella and the acts related.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 28.02.28, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1928/02/28/pagina-9/33201434/pdf.html here]</ref> [[File:4columnes fotoantiga.jpg|thumb|Barcelona, 1929]] There is scarce information on Iglesias' public activity during the last few years of his life. Until death he remained employed as the Catalan delegado de Hacienda.<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 27.01.32, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1933/01/19/pagina-6/33189077/pdf.html here]</ref> In June 1931 he was rumored to run on a joint right-wing ticket for the Cortes<ref>''La Galeria'' 03.06.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3062115&interno=S&posicion=14&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> and indeed later that year he was once noted as speaking at a Traditionalism-flavored rally,<ref>''La Cruz'' 29.10.31, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3059037&interno=S&posicion=5&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> yet unlike many former Mellistas, Iglesias has not been reported as engaged in a re-united Carlist organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]].<ref>no press information confirms his activity within Carlism after 1931, he is also missing in the most comprehensive work on Carlism of the era, Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}</ref> Since the early 1920s he was plagued by health problems,<ref>''Las Provincias'' 11.09.24, available [http://prensahistorica.mcu.es/es/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=1000319397&interno=S&posicion=6&presentacion=pagina here]</ref> yet their nature is not clear and it is not known what caused his premature death. Many periodicals noted his passing away, including at least one Carlist paper.<ref>the exception was ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'', which printed a corteous and informative necrological note, see ''El Siglo Futuro'' 16.01.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000506447&page=6 here]</ref>
==See also==

{{Infobox person | name = Elizabeth Hanna | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|4|2}} | birth_place = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada | education = [[National Theatre School of Canada]]
[[Carleton University]]
[[University of Toronto]] | occupation = [[Actress]], [[speech-language pathologist]] | yearsactive = 1980–present }} '''Elizabeth Hanna''' (born April 2, 1953) is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] film and television [[actress]], most notable for her [[voice acting]] work in [[animated film]]s. She later complemented her voice acting skills by becoming a [[speech-language pathologist]]. == History == ===Early history=== Elizabeth Hanna spent her early years in [[Ottawa]], where she graduated from [[Glebe Collegiate Institute]].Where she was preceded by [[Luba Goy]], later of the [[Royal Canadian Air Farce]]. Both also graduated from the [[National Theatre School of Canada]]. Both also have done extensive voice-acting work in productions for [[Nelvana]], including performing together in such productions as ''[[The Care Bears Adventure in Wonderland]].'' She attended [[Carleton University]], where she graduated with a major in [[philosophy]].And where some of her undergraduate work was published. See reference to her "The '6's' in the ''Tractatus''", published in Vol 1(2) of ''The Carleton University Student Journal of Philosophy'' (Summer, 1974), [https://carleton.ca/philosophy/cusjp/paperissues.html CUSJP Issues Printed on Paper]; www.carleton.ca/philosophy/cusjp, in which Hanna discusses [[Ludwig Wittgenstein|Ludwig Wittgenstein's]] sixth proposition from his ''[[Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus]] ''. Hanna's research and analytical orientations have continued in her later career as a speech-language pathologist: see "Selected Recent Presentations/Publications" at [http://www.clearspeech.ca/profile.htm Profile of Elizabeth Hanna]; www.clearspeech.ca.One of Hanna's contemporaries during her time at Carleton was comedian [[Dan Aykroyd]]. She was then accepted into the [[National Theatre School of Canada]], based in [[Montreal]], Quebec, from which she graduated in 1977.{{cite web|url=http://www.ent-nts.ca/en/alumni/all/acting/1970.aspx |title=Alumni, Acting: 1970-1979 |publisher=National Theatre School of Canada |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421213221/http://www.ent-nts.ca/en/alumni/all/acting/1970.aspx |archivedate=2012-04-21 |df= }}One of Hanna's classmates at the National Theatre School was Canadian actor, writer and director [[Jack Blum]]. ===Acting career=== Hanna then relocated to [[Toronto]], where she continues to be based. She initially commenced her professional acting career appearing in various Toronto stage productions. She also began to obtain commercial [[voice-over]] work, contributing to national television and radio advertising campaigns. This led to the development of her career as a [[Voice acting|voice actor]] in a number of [[animated films]] associated with such well-known characters as [[The Little Bear Movie|Little Bear]], the [[Care Bears]], [[Babar the Elephant]], and [[Sailor Moon (character)|Sailor Moon]].[http://www.clearspeech.ca/profile.htm Profile of Elizabeth Hanna]; www.clearspeech.ca. Much of Hanna's voice acting work has been in productions of the [[Nelvana]] group. ===As a speech-language pathologist=== Hanna later complemented her voice acting and voiceover skills by obtaining a [[Master of Health Science]] degree, majoring in [[Speech-Language Pathology]], from the [[University of Toronto]]. She commenced practising as a Speech-Language Pathologist in 1996 while continuing her voice and other contributions to film and television, as well as voice contributions to [[video game]]s. == Filmography == *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1344959/ "The Dating Guy"] (2009) (TV Series) Primarily from the Internet Movie Database, as supplemented. For further details, see [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0360200/ Elizabeth Hanna Filmography]; www.imdb.com. *[http://www.tv.com/the-future-is-wild/show/74890/summary.html?tag=page_nav;main "The Future Is Wild"] (2007) (TV Series, [[Discovery Kids]])One episode, [http://www.tv.com/the-future-is-wild/sky-high-anxiety/episode/1149626/summary.html "Sky High Anxiety".] *''[[Care Bears: Big Wish Movie]]'' (2005) *''[[Rolie Polie Olie]]: The Baby Bot Chase'' (2003) *''[[The Little Bear Movie]]'' (2001) *''[[Franklin and the Green Knight|Franklin and the Green Knight: The Movie]]'' (2000)See also [[List of Franklin characters]]. *''[[Mega Man Legends 2]]'' (2000) (Video Game) *''[[Mythic Warriors: Guardians of the Legend]]'' (2000) (TV Series) *''[[The Misadventures of Tron Bonne]]'' (1999) (Video Game) *''[[Babar: King of the Elephants]]'' (1999) *''[[Silver Surfer (1998 TV series)|Silver Surfer]]'' (1998) (TV Series) *''[[Mega Man Legends (video game)|Mega Man Legends]]'' (1997) (Video Game) *''[[Sailor Moon (character)|Sailor Moon]]'' (1995) (TV Series)One episode, [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1344959/ "Treed"] (1995); www.imdb.com. *''[[The Magic School Bus (TV series)|The Magic School Bus]]'' (1995) (TV Series)One episode, [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0851801/ "Taking Flight"] (1995); www.imdb.com. *''[[Little Bear (TV series)|Little Bear]]'' (1995-2003) (TV Series) *''[[Wild C.A.T.s (TV series)|Wild C.A.T.s]]'' (1994–1995) (TV Series) *''[[Tales from the Cryptkeeper]]'' (1993–1994) (TV Series)See also [[The Haunt of Fear]]. *"[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0108590/fullcredits#cast Woman on the Run:] The [[Lawrencia Bembenek]] Story" (1993) (Television Movie) *''[[Dog City]]'' (1992–1995) (TV Series) *''[[Beetlejuice (TV series)|Beetlejuice]]'' (1989–1991) (TV Series)Hanna voiced the character of [[Delia Deetz]], who was played in the [[Beetlejuice|1988 film]] by [[Catherine O'Hara]]. {{more footnotes|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox language |name=Emilian |altname=Emiliano |nativename=Emigliân |pronunciation = |states=[[Italy]] |region = * [[Emilia-Romagna]] (northern and central [[province of Piacenza]], northern and southeastern [[Province of Parma]], [[Province of Reggio Emilia]], [[Province of Modena]], western and central [[Metropolitan City of Bologna]], [[Province of Ferrara]]) * [[Lombardy]] (southern [[province of Pavia]], southern [[province of Cremona]], central and southern [[province of Mantua]]) * [[Tuscany]] (municipality of [[Sambuca Pistoiese]]) * [[Piedmont]] (eastern [[province of Alessandria]]) * [[Liguria]] (eastern [[province of La Spezia]]) * [[Veneto]] (southern [[province of Rovigo]]) |ethnicity=3.3 million (2008)<ref>[http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/cr_files/2008-040_egl.pdf ISO change request]</ref> |speakers=ca. 1.3 million |date=2006 |ref=<ref>[http://www3.istat.it/salastampa/comunicati/non_calendario/20070420_00/testointegrale.pdf La lingua italiana, i dialetti e le lingue straniere Anno 2006]</ref> |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam4=[[Western Romance languages|Western]] |fam5=[[Gallo-Italic]] |fam6=[[Emiliano-Romagnolo language|Emiliano-Romagnolo]] |dialects=[[Bolognese dialect|Bolognese]], Ferrarese, Modenese, Reggiano, [[Parmigiano dialect|Parmigiano]], Piacentino<!--ref name="e17" /--> |script = [[Latin script|Latin]] |minority= |agency= |iso3=egl |glotto=emil1241 |glottorefname=Emiliano |lingua=51-AAA-oka ... -okh }}
'''Emilian''' is a group of [[dialect]]s of the [[Emilian-Romagnol language]] spoken in the area historically called [[Emilia (region of Italy)|Emilia]], the western portion of today's [[Emilia-Romagna]] region in [[Italy]].
There is no standardised version of Emilian.
The default word order is [[subject–verb–object]]. There are two [[grammatical gender|gender]]s as well as a distinction between plural and singular. Emilian has a strong [[T–V distinction]] to distinguish varying levels of politeness, social distance, courtesy, familiarity or insult. Its alphabet uses a considerable number of [[diacritic]]s.
==Classification== {{Main|Emilian-Romagnol language|Gallo-Italic languages}} Emilian is a dialect of the [[Emilian-Romagnol language]], one of the [[Gallo-Italic languages]]. There is a high degree of [[mutual intelligibility]] between the various varieties of Emilian and the other dialect, [[Romagnol dialect|Romagnol]]. The Gallo-Italic family has Emilian-Romagnol, [[Piedmontese language|Piedmontese]], [[Ligurian (Romance language)|Ligurian]] and [[Lombard language|Lombard]].
==Dialects== [[Linguasphere Observatory]] recognises the following dialects:<ref>{{cite web| url=http://linguasphere.info/?page=inner&id_inner=1017741| work=Linguasphere |title=51-AAA-ok. emiliano + romagnolo}}</ref> *'''Mantovano''', spoken in all but the very north of the [[Province of Mantua]] in Lombardy. It has a strong Lombard influence. *'''Vogherese (Pavese-Vogherese)''', spoken in the [[Province of Pavia]] in Lombardy. It is closely related phonetically and morphologically to Piacentino. It is also akin to Tortonese.{{what|date=October 2013}} *'''Piacentino''', spoken west of the [[Taro (river)|River Taro]] in the [[Province of Piacenza]] and on the border with the province of Parma. The variants of Piacentino are strongly influenced by Lombard, Piedmontese, and Ligurian. *'''[[Parmigiano dialect|Parmigiano]]''', spoken in the [[Province of Parma]]. Those from the area refer to the Parmigiano spoken outside of Parma as Arioso or Parmense, although today's urban and rural dialects are so mixed that only a few speak the original. The language spoken in [[Casalmaggiore]] in the [[Province of Cremona]] to the north of Parma is closely related to Parmigiano. *'''Reggiano''', spoken in the [[Province of Reggio Emilia]], although the northern parts (such as [[Guastalla]], [[Luzzara]] and [[Reggiolo]]) of the province are not part of this group and closer to Mantovano. *'''Modenese''', spoken in the [[Province of Modena]], although Bolognese is more widespread in the Castelfranco area. In the northern part of the province of Modena, the lowlands around the town of Mirandola, a Mirandolese sub-dialect of Modenese is spoken. *'''[[Bolognese dialect|Bolognese]]''', spoken in the [[Metropolitan City of Bologna]] and in around [[Castelfranco Emilia]], Modena. *'''Ferrarese''', spoken in the [[Province of Ferrara]], southern [[Veneto]], and [[Comacchio]].
Other definitions include the following:{{cn|date=October 2013}} * '''Carrarese''' and '''Lunigiano''' dialects, spoken in [[Carrara]], [[Lunigiana]], in almost all of the [[Province of Massa and Carrara]] in northwestern [[Tuscany]], and a good portion of the [[Province of La Spezia]] in eastern [[Liguria]]. Historically, this region has been part of Tuscany and the duchies of [[Duchy of Modena|Modena]] and [[Duchy of Parma|Parma]] at different times, so it has a close economic relationship with the Emilian area and is geographically proximate due to the [[Magra (river)|Magra]] and [[Vara (river)|Vara]] rivers. * '''Massese''' (mixed with some Tuscan features) * '''Casalasco''', spoken in [[Cremona]], [[Lombardy]].
==Writing system== Emilian is written using a [[Latin script]] that has never been standardised. As a result, spelling varies widely across the dialects. The dialects are largely oral and rarely written. However, the [[Bible]] was published in Emilian-Romagnol in 1865; the work has since been lost.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forum-intl.net/find_a_bible/?Language=eml |title=Emiliano-Romagnolo [eml] |publisher=forum-intl.net }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== * Colombini, F. 2007. La negazione nei dialetti emiliani: microvariazione nell’area modenese. [[University of Padua]], MA Thesis.
==Further reading== * Pietro Mainoldi, Manuale dell'odierno dialetto bolognese, Suoni e segni, Grammatica - Vocabolario, Bologna, Società tipografica Mareggiani 1950 (Rist. anast.: Sala Bolognese, A. Forni 2000) * Fabio Foresti, Bibliografia dialettale dell'Emilia-Romagna e della Repubblica di San Marino (BDER), Bologna, IBACN Emilia-Romagna / Compositori 1997 * E. F. Tuttle, Nasalization in Northern Italy: Syllabic Constraints and Strength Scales as Developmental Parameters, Rivista di Linguistica, III: 23-92 (1991) * Luigi Lepri e Daniele Vitali, Dizionario Bolognese-Italiano Italiano-Bolognese, ed. Pendragon 2007
==External links== {{Incubator|egl|Wiktionary}} {{wiktionary category|category=Emilian language}} * [http://starling.rinet.ru/cgi-bin/response.cgi?root=new100&morpho=0&basename=new100\ier\rom&first=0 Emilian basic lexicon at the Global Lexicostatistical Database]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=November 2010}} '''Enduring Voices''' is a project for documenting world's [[endangered language]]s and trying to prevent language extinction by identifying the most crucial areas where languages are endangered and embarking on expeditions to record these languages. Launched in 2007 by the joint effort of the [[Living Tongues Institute for Endangered Languages]] and the [[National Geographic Society]], it has organized expeditions to language "hotspots" around the world, e.g. to [[Australia]], [[Bolivia]], [[East India]]. Enduring Voices tries to understand the geographic dimensions of language distribution, determine how linguistic diversity is linked to biodiversity and bring wider attention to the issue of language loss. The Enduring Voices Project assists indigenous communities in their efforts to revitalize and maintain their threatened languages.
The Language Hotspots model for prioritizing language research was conceived and developed by Dr. Greg Anderson and K. David Harrison at the Living Tongues Institute for Endangered Languages to identify most endangered and least studied languages. It is a new way to view the distribution of global linguistic diversity, to assess the threat of language extinction, and to. Hotspots are those regions of the world having the greatest linguistic diversity, the greatest language endangerment, and the least-studied languages. For the project, Doctors Anderson and Harrison are accompanied by Chris Rainier,<ref>[http://www.chrisrainier.com/ Chris Rainier website about his involvement with National Geographic Enduring Voices Project]</ref> a National Geographic Fellow and ethnographic photographer and filmmaker for helping in documenting various linguistic expedition on camera and film.
Identified hotspots with degrees of threat of language extinction include: *Severe: North West Pacific Plateau (USA),<ref>[http://www.actionatlas.org/cultures/endangered-languages/enduring-voices-northwest-pacific-plateau/summary/paaACFE5138100630605 ActionAtlas: Discover and preserve endangered languages of the Northwest Pacific Coast]</ref> Central South America, Central Siberia, Eastern Siberia and Northern Australia *High: Oklahoma Southwest, Southern South America, *Medium: Northern South America, Western Melanesia *Low: MesoAmerica, Western Africa, Eastern Africa, Southern Africa, Caucasus, Eastern India and Malaysia, SouthEast Asia, Eastern Melanesia and Taiwan-Philippines. In each of these area, Enduring Voices has identified languages as priorities for research before it is too late.
Through the efforts of the Enduring Voices Project, the [[Koro language (India)|Koro language]] was discovered in India in 2008.<ref>[http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/10/101005-lost-language-india-science National Geographic: Hidden language found in remote Indian tribe]</ref> During a three-week trip in 2009, the Enduring Voices team recorded interviews with speakers of eleven indigenous languages of Papua New Guinea.<ref>[http://www.swarthmore.edu/SocSci/Linguistics/SlidePics/PapuaReport.pdf Living Tongues Institute: Enduring Voices—Papua New Guinea]</ref>
